❌ First metatarsophalangeal joint sprain :
Incorrect: First metatarsophalangeal joint sprains result from an injury to the big toe secondary to forced hyperextension. This patient does not have evidence of an isolated digit injury.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the primary care office because of trouble with vision. Over the past two weeks, the patient has been experiencing intermittent episodes of blue-tinted vision, which resolve within a few hours each time. He woke up today with blurry vision in the right eye. There is no eye pain, conjunctival redness, or headache. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, type II diabetes mellitus, and erectile dysfunction. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the drug responsible for this patient’s current symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule
Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with a transient, bluish visual discoloration, afferent pupillary defect, decreased visual acuity, and optic disc edema in the right eye, together with a history of erectile dysfunction, is most likely due to an adverse effect of a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor (e.g., sildenafil, vardenafil, tadalafil). These agents are first-line medical therapy for erectile dysfunction. They can also be used to treat pulmonary hypertension.    

PDE-5 is responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inhibitors with a resultant decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells, leading to smooth muscle relaxation (by enhancing NO activity). The net result is pulmonary vasodilation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis.    

Therefore, PDE-5 inhibitors are usually indicated in the treatment of erectile dysfunction (enhances the erectile response to sexual stimulation), pulmonary hypertension (reduces pulmonary vascular resistance), and benign prostate hyperplasia (only tadalafil specifically). Common side effects include facial flushing, headache, dyspepsia, hearing loss, and hypotension (when used with nitrates or alpha-adrenergic blockers). Sildenafil cross-reacts with PDE-6 in the retina and can cause transient blue vision (as seen in this patient). Rarely, non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (NAION) can occur.  



Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase :
Incorrect: Statins act by inhibiting hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase, leading to a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling. Common side effects include hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal discomfort, and rash. The blue-tinted vision seen in this patient is not associated with stains. 
❌ Inhibition of mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase :
Incorrect: Metformin (used for diabetes mellitus) inhibits gluconeogenesis by inhibiting mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase. Side effects include weight loss, gastrointestinal upset, and possibly lactic acidosis. Blue-tinted vision is not associated with metformin. 
❌ Inhibition of sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 in renal tubule :
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose co-transporter two inhibitors (e.g. canagliflozin) act on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption of glucose. Common adverse effects include urinary tract infections, vulvovaginal candidiasis, hypotension, and acute kidney injury. They are not associated with visual disturbances. 
❌ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-3 in platelets :
Incorrect: Antiplatelet phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitors (e.g., cilostazol) inhibit platelet aggregation via increased cAMP in platelets. Common side effects include dizziness, headaches, palpitations, and gastrointestinal disturbance. They do not affect vision. 
✅ Inhibition of phosphodiesterase-5 in the endothelial cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to chest pain which started an hour ago while playing soccer with his grandchild. He describes a crushing pain that radiates down the left arm and is rated as eight on a ten-point scale. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, and erectile dysfunction. Current medications include atorvastatin, lisinopril, metformin, and sildenafil. Family history is noncontributory. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily, drinks five to six beers on weekends, and does not use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 102/minute, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 150/89 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and cardiac examination shows no murmurs. A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) is shown below. Which of the following medications, if administered, is most likely to result in serious complications in this patient? 


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with typical chest pain in combination with ECG findings of ST-elevation in anterior precordial leads is suggestive of ST-elevation myocardial (STEMI). Nitroglycerin administration should be avoided in this patient due to the risk of profound hypotension when given together with sildenafil, a phosphodiesterase-5 (PDE-5) inhibitor.    

Nitrates are converted to nitric oxide, which promotes the conversion of guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP). An increase in cGMP leads to vascular smooth muscle relaxation. PDE-5 is normally responsible for the breakdown of cGMP and is inhibited by PDE-5 inibitors (e.g. sildenafil). PDE-5 inhibition causes a decrease in the hydrolysis of cGMP in vascular smooth muscle cells. This results in the accumulation of cGMP, leading to excessive vasodilation and profound hypotension when used in combination with nitrates (which also cause accumulation of cGMP).    



Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin :
Incorrect: The antiplatelet effects of aspirin are significant in patients with acute coronary syndrome (ACS). 325 mg aspirin should be administered as part of initial management in all patients with suspected myocardial infarction (MI). 
❌ Clopidogrel :
Incorrect: Patients with ACS should receive dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and another antiplatelet agent (e.g., clopidogrel, prasugrel, ticagrelor) before primary percutaneous intervention (PCI) or fibrinolytic therapy. It can be safely administered to this patient. 
❌ Enoxaparin :
Incorrect: Enoxaparin, low molecular weight heparin, is indicated in ACS to prevent intraluminal clot extension, formation, and re-infarction. It should be avoided in patients with contraindication to anticoagulants (e.g., history of cerebral aneurysm or arteriovenous malformation, intracranial neoplasm) and used cautiously if any recent (within the past six months) thromboembolic stroke. 
❌ Fentanyl :
Incorrect: Adequate analgesia is important for managing pain and anxiety (with resultant tachycardia). Fentanyl can be safely administered to this patient. 
✅ Nitroglycerin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing sudden onset of palpitations. An initial electrocardiogram demonstrates paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia at a rate of 160/min. He is given several doses of adenosine without termination of the arrhythmia. The primary physician discusses the case with the on-call electrophysiologist, who recommends administering a medication which affects the cardiac action potential in the manner designated in the figure below. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia refractory to management with adenosine. He is subsequently given a medication that exerts a strong sodium channel blockade with no effect on the duration of the action potential, which is consistent with the mechanism of action of a class IC antiarrhythmic medications. Among the answer choices, only propafone is from this medication class.        

Class I antiarrhythmics are divided into three major classes--A, B, and C. However, all of them work via sodium channel blockade. Sodium channel blockade slows the upstroke of the sodium-dependent action potential (phase 0) and subsequently prolongs the QRS interval.        

Moreover, some of the class I antiarrhythmics have an effect on potassium channels and alter the action potential duration. Group 1A prolongs the action potential duration (due to potassium channel inhibition), 1B shortens the duration (due to potassium channel activation), and 1C has no effect on action potential duration (no effect of potassium channels).        

Understanding which medications are associated with each class and their subsequent effect on the ventricular action potential is an important concept for Step 1.  



Option Analysis

✅ Propafenone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Diltiazem:
Incorrect: Diltiazem is a class IV antiarrhythmic medication that can be used for rate control in patients with supraventricular tachycardias. However, diltiazem does not affect the ventricular cardiac action potential and would not alter the slope of the initial upstroke.  
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic medication and does not affect phase 0 of ventricular depolarization.  
❌ Procainamide  :
Incorrect: Procainamide exhibits moderate sodium channel blockade. However, it also has some potassium channel-blocking effects, which increase the action potential duration and effective refractory period.  
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Of all the class I antiarrhythmic medications, lidocaine exhibits the weakest effect on sodium channel blockade and will also decrease the action potential duration.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department following a syncopal episode while at the grocery store. He experienced a sensation of light-headedness and fluttering in his chest before subsequently passing out. The patient states his medical history includes a "heart condition." Brief chart review demonstrates an echocardiogram performed one month ago, which shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 35%. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 162/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 118/82 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates a hyperdynamic precordium and bibasilar crackles on pulmonary auscultation. Initial ECG shows ventricular tachycardia with left axis deviation. He is subsequently initiated on an antiarrhythmic medication and admitted to the coronary care unit. On the second day of hospitalization, he is noted to have a blood pressure of 86/58 mm Hg and jugular venous distention. Laboratory studies show an elevated brain natriuretic protein level. Which of the following medications is the most likely precipitant of this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of diminished cardiac output is given an antiarrhythmic agent and subsequently develops findings of acute heart failure. Of the medications listed, only disopyramide is known to induce acute decompensated heart failure in patients with known impaired cardiac contractility.        

Disopyramide is a class IA antiarrhythmic that is used most often to treat ventricular arrhythmias and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. This class of drugs works by inhibiting voltage-dependent fast sodium channels in cardiac muscle cells. When an electrical current propagates down the heart and reaches a myocyte, the nearby fast sodium channels typically open and allow a large rush of sodium ions into the cell, quickly raising the charge of the inner cellular membrane from negative to positive. This influx of sodium ions is stopped by the closing of the channel's inactivation gate, which reacts more slowly to the depolarization than to the channel's opening function.        

By serving as a fast sodium channel blocker in both the atria and the ventricles, disopyramide is able to slow the speed at which the heart depolarizes as an organized unit, and also decrease the strength of the heart's contractions. As such, one of disopyramide's feared complications is acute heart failure, and thus it cannot be used in patients with impaired systolic function.   

Option Analysis

✅ Disopyramide:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a class IB antiarrhythmic that works by blocking sodium channels and preferentially affects ischemic tissue and Purkinje fibers. Its notable side effects include paresthesias, seizures, respiratory depression, and central nervous system depression. However, it would not account for this patient’s decompensated heart failure. 
❌ Mexiletine:
Incorrect: Mexiletine is a class IB antiarrhythmic that works by blocking sodium channels and preferentially affects ischemic tissue and Purkinje fibers. Its notable side effect is gastrointestinal upset. 
❌ Procainamide:
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class IA antiarrhythmic that works in the same manner as disopyramide via fast sodium channel blockade. It is a known cause of drug-induced lupus. 
❌ Quinidine:
Incorrect: Quinidine is a class IA antiarrhythmic that works in the same manner as disopyramide via fast sodium channel blockade. It is known to cause cinchonism, which is characterized by headaches and tinnitus.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic with sudden severe left eye pain that started a few hours ago. She describes the pain as sharp and throbbing, and it is associated with a severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. She reports seeing halos around lights and having blurry vision. She has a history of hyperopia but no previous eye problems. Visual acuity is decreased in the left eye and normal in the right eye. On examination of the left eye, there is conjunctival erythema and a dilated nonreactive pupil. The right eye is within normal limits. Which of the following examination findings would be consistent with the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      22 mmHg     Normal anterior chamber angle
Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      54 mmHg     Narrow anterior chamber angle
Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      18 mmHg    Narrow anterior chamber angle
Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      35 mmHg    Wide anterior chamber angle

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms consistent with acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is an ophthalmic emergency characterized by sudden, dramatic increase in intraocular pressure (IOP) due to blockage of aqueous humor drainage. The IOP is often significantly elevated, typically above 40 mmHg. An IOP of 54 mmHg and gonioscopy showing a narrow anterior chamber angle is consistent with acute angle closure glaucoma.        

In acute closure glaucoma, the IOP is often significantly elevated and associated with a narrow or closed anterior chamber angle. In contrast, with open-angle glaucoma there is usually a gradual rise in IOP (above 21 mmHg) but lower than in acute angle closure glaucoma. Gonioscopy in open-angle glaucoma would show a wide or normal anterior chamber angle, indicating that the drainage pathway remains open but is less effective at regulating pressure.  



Option Analysis

❌  Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      15 mmHg      Normal anterior chamber angle     :
Incorrect: This combination of findings is consistent with a normal eye exam without evidence of glaucoma. The patient in this vignette most likely has acute angle-closure glaucoma, which is associated with a significantly IOP and narrow anterior chamber. 
❌  Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      22 mmHg     Normal anterior chamber angle :
Incorrect: An IOP of 22 mmHg represents an increased IOP but does not fit with the severe presentation of acute angle-closure glaucoma, where IOP is typically significantly elevated and the anterior chamber is narrow. 
✅  Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      54 mmHg     Narrow anterior chamber angle :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      18 mmHg    Narrow anterior chamber angle :
Incorrect: While a narrow angle would be consistent with acute angle closure glaucoma, patients with acute angle closure glaucoma typically have a significantly elevated IOP.  
❌  Intraocular pressure (IOP)      Gonioscopy findings      35 mmHg    Wide anterior chamber angle :
Incorrect: An elevated IOP with a wide anterior chamber angle could suggest open-angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension but not acute angle-closure glaucoma, where a narrow chamber would be expected.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman presents to the urgent care clinic because her friend at school had infectious mononucleosis two weeks ago, and the patient wants to be tested. For the past three days, the patient has had a low-grade fever and a sore throat. She has not had a cough. She is not sexually active and does not use alcohol, tobacco, or other recreational substances. Temperature is 38.3 ºC (101.0 ºF), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min and blood pressure is 112/72 mmHg. On physical exam, there are multiple swollen tender lymph nodes in the anterior cervical chain bilaterally. The tonsils are erythematous, enlarged, and exudative.  Serum heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 18-year-old girl presents for evaluation of sore throat and low-grade fevers and is requesting testing for mononucleosis. The negative heterophile antibody and anti-EBV viral capsid IgM tests rule out infectious mononucleosis (IM). Based on the Centor Criteria, which is used to determine the need for testing for streptococcal pharyngitis, this patient has a score of 4 (age 15-44 yo, tonsillar exudates, anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, fever, absence of cough), and likely has streptococcal pharyngitis.    

IM and streptococcal pharyngitis can present similarly, though strep pharyngitis is more often associated with tender swollen lymphadenopathy in the anterior cervical chain, and symptoms of IM are more often prolonged. If IM is suspected, serum heterophile antibody testing should be performed. If this is positive, then IM is confirmed. However, it is common to have false negative results early in the disease course therefore If heterophile antibody testing is negative and IM is strongly suggested, a complete blood count and peripheral smear should be performed. If the absolute lymphocyte count >4000/mm3 OR >50% OR >10% atypical lymphocytes are seen on the peripheral smear, then anti-EBV viral capsid IgM testing should be performed; and if this is positive, then IM is confirmed. If the anti-EBV viral capsid IgM testing is negative, then a search for an alternative diagnosis should be pursued.   

Option Analysis

✅ Streptococcal pharyngitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Infectious mononucleosis:
Incorrect: While infectious mononucleosis is a common cause of sore throat and fever in this age group, the patient’s significant anterior cervical lymphadenopathy and negative serum testing suggest strep pharyngitis. 
❌ Epstein-Barr virus infection:
Incorrect: Immunocompetent/healthy young patients like this one who are infected with Epstein-Barr virus infection can develop infectious mononucleosis; however, given the negative testing and significant anterior cervical lymphadenopathy, streptococcal pharyngitis (“strep throat”) is more likely. 
❌ Primary cytomegalovirus infection:
Incorrect: In young healthy patients, primary cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection is typically asymptomatic. CMV can lead to various infectious syndromes in immunocompromised patients like those who have had bone marrow or solid organ transplantation. 
❌ Lemierre syndrome:
Incorrect: Patients with Lemierre syndrome, a rare complication of bacterial pharyngitis, typically present with unilateral neck pain, swelling, and fever due to septic thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein. This patient does not show these findings or a prolonged course characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the urgent care clinic desiring testing for infectious mononucleosis. The patient’s girlfriend was diagnosed with mononucleosis last week. The patient has had a fever, fatigue, myalgias, and a mild sore throat for the past 2 days. past medical history is significant for severe peptic ulcer disease. Current medication includes lansoprazole and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical exam, the patient appears fatigued. Posterior cervical lymphadenopathy and palatal petechiae are present along with erythematous enlarged tonsils bilaterally. Serum heterophile antibody is obtained and is negative. Peripheral smear shows >10% atypical lymphocytes And Anti-EBV viral capsid IgM is positive. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 17-year-old boy with recent exposure to infectious mononucleosis (IM) presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of this disease. Subsequent serum testing confirms the diagnosis of IM. Acetaminophen can be given as an antipyretic as part of supportive treatment.    

Patients with IM typically present with fever, fatigue, myalgias, and sore throat. On physical exam, patients may have tonsillar erythema and exudates, posterior cervical chain lymphadenopathy, and occasionally splenomegaly. Diagnosis of IM can be confirmed with a positive heterophile antibody or anti-EBV viral capsid IgM test.   

The treatment of IM is supportive. Patients should be counseled about the need for rest and adequate hydration. Patients should be treated with anti-pyrectics such as acetaminophen, and they may benefit from the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen). In this patient with severe peptic ulcer disease, the use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatories is contraindicated. Patients should also be counseled to avoid strenuous exercise or contact sports for three weeks given the risk of splenic rupture.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acetaminophen:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Repeat heterophile antibody testing:
Incorrect: The patient’s exposure history, physical examination, and IgM testing support a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis. Repeating the heterophile antibody is not necessary currently. 
❌ Ibuprofen:
Incorrect: While nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are an appropriate supportive treatment for patients with infectious mononucleosis, this patient’s severe peptic ulcer disease makes this class of agents contraindicated. 
❌ Ganciclovir:
Incorrect: Ganciclovir is used to treat cytomegalovirus infections and certain severe Epstein-Barr virus infections such as viral hepatitis. It is not indicated for treatment of infectious mononucleosis. 
❌ Evaluate for an alternative diagnosis :
Incorrect: The patient’s exposure history, physical examination, and IgM testing all support infectious mononucleosis and the patient should be treated with supportive measures.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents to the clinic with a concern about developing prostate cancer. He has been experiencing worsening urinary frequency, difficulty initiating urination, and waking up three to four times per night to urinate over the past year. There is no associated hematuria, weight loss, or back pain. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, managed with lisinopril. He has no family history of prostate cancer and does not smoke or drink alcohol. He has a co-worker who was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer, and the patient is worried he needs screening. On physical examination, the abdomen is soft, non-tender, and without palpable bladder distension. A digital rectal examination (DRE) reveals a nontender symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodules. Urinalysis is negative for infection, and there is no hematuria. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Engage in shared decision-making regarding whether to pursue prostate cancer screening
Order prostate biopsy to rule out malignancy
Repeat DRE and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing in 6 months
Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the prostate

questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms consistent with benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) and expresses concern about prostate cancer screening. Although BPH and prostate cancer both affect the prostate, BPH does not increase the risk of prostate cancer, and no specific monitoring or screening for prostate cancer is recommended in patients with BPH.        

Patients with BPH can be asymptomatic or they can present with storage or irritative symptoms and/or voiding symptoms. Storage symptoms include urinary frequency, urgency, ոоϲtսriа, and incontinence. Voiding symptoms include slow urinary stream, straining to void, urinary intermittency (stream starting and stopping), hesitancy, and terminal dribbling. On digital rectal exam (DRE) in patients with BPH, the prostate is symmetrically enlarged and smooth.        

BPH is not associated with systemic symptoms and does not increase the risk of prostate cancer. In contrast, patients with prostate cancer may present with similar urinary symptoms, but they often have red-flag signs such as unintentional weight loss, bone pain, or hematuria if advanced. On DRE, prostate cancer may be suggested by an asymmetric gland, nodules, or induration. Additionally, a persistently elevated or rapidly rising PSA level is concerning for malignancy, particularly when coupled with abnormal DRE findings or a family history of prostate cancer.       

The current guidelines for screening for prostate cancer in men aged 55 to 69 years recommend discussion and shared decision-making regarding screening with PSA and/or DRE. Routine screening, such as with annual PSA testing, is not recommended as it has not demonstrated a significant mortality benefit and can lead to overdiagnosis and overtreatment. During discussions on shared decision-making, the patient’s risk factors (e.g., age, family history) and personal preferences should be discussed to help make an informed choice about whether to pursue PSA screening. Shared decision-making should include discussions about the benefits, risks, and limitations of prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing and treatments.   

Option Analysis

❌ Check prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels annually:
Incorrect: Routine PSA testing is not advised. PSA levels should only be checked if, after a discussion and shared decision-making, the patient chooses to proceed with screening. 
✅ Engage in shared decision-making regarding whether to pursue prostate cancer screening:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order prostate biopsy to rule out malignancy:
Incorrect: A prostate biopsy is an invasive procedure and should only be performed if there is a high clinical suspicion of prostate cancer. Indications for a biopsy include persistently elevated prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels, abnormal findings on DRE (e.g., nodules or asymmetry), or symptoms that suggest advanced disease (e.g., unexplained weight loss, or bone pain).  
❌ Repeat DRE and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) testing in 6 months:
Incorrect: Routine follow-up with DRE and PSA testing at fixed intervals, such as every six months, is not recommended unless clinical concerns require ongoing monitoring. These tests should only be performed as part of a shared decision-making process or if there is evidence of progression in symptoms or risk factors.  
❌ Multiparametric magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the prostate:
Incorrect: A multiparametric MRI is a diagnostic tool used to evaluate prostate lesions when prostate cancer is strongly suspected, such as in patients with elevated prostate-specific antigen or abnormal DRE. However, it is not a screening test and should not be performed in asymptomatic patients or in those with symptomatic benign prostatic hypertrophy (BPH) without signs of prostate cancer.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe muscle pain, weakness, dark tea-colored urine, and decreased urine output after completing a marathon yesterday. He reports running in extremely hot and humid conditions. He does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or a recent infection. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 96/64 mmHg, heart rate is 98 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient’s mucous membranes appear dry, and there is tenderness in the muscles of the calves and thighs bilaterally. There is also bilateral lower extremity swelling. No bruising is noted. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Neurologic examination reveals normal reflexes and intact sensation. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Laboratory value       Result     
 Creatinine      4.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL)     
 Blood urea nitrogen      55 mg/dL     
 Potassium      5.3 mEq/L     
 Creatine kinase      50,000 U/L     
 Urinalysis      1+ protein, no red blood cells, dark colored urine
questions.solution:
This patient presents with rhabdomyolysis (due to extreme physical exertion) and an associated acute kidney injury (AKI). Rhabdomyolysis refers to a condition where skeletal muscle breaks down and releases myoglobin into the bloodstream, which precipitates in renal tubules and induces direct tubular damage and obstruction, leading to an intrinsic AKI. The most appropriate initial treatment for this condition is intravenous (IV) fluid administration, which increases renal perfusion, dilutes the toxic effects of myoglobin, and promotes myoglobin excretion through the urine, thus preventing further kidney damage.       

Intrinsic AKI refers to a sudden decline in kidney function resulting in electrolyte disturbance and accumulation of nitrogenous waste (i.e. ammonia and uric acid). Both glomerular damage and non-glomerular injury affecting the tubules or interstitium can cause this condition. For patients presenting with AKI, the initial step is performing an ABCDE assessment to determine if patients are unstable or stable. For unstable patients, stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation is the priority. IV access, fluid resuscitation, and monitoring are the most appropriate initial steps in treatment. Emergent hemodialysis may be necessary for patients with AKI from rhabdomyolysis who experience severe complications like hyperkalemia or uremia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Corticosteroids :
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are not indicated for the treatment of rhabdomyolysis with acute kidney injury. The primary treatment is volume resuscitation and supportive care.
✅  Intravenous (IV) fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemodialysis:
Incorrect: While this patient has evidence of an acute kidney injury (AKI), there is no urgent indication for dialysis (e.g., refractory hyperkalemia, severe metabolic acidosis, fluid overload). Fluid administration is the main treatment. 
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate can be used to alkalinize the urine in cases of severe rhabdomyolysis. This functions to prevent myoglobin precipitation in the kidneys; however, IV fluid administration is the best initial treatment. 
❌ Kidney biopsy:
Incorrect: A kidney biopsy is not indicated as the diagnosis of rhabdomyolysis with acute kidney injury (AKI) is clear based on history, clinical presentation, and laboratory findings.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presents with one month of worsening back pain in the lumbar and thoracic spine. He reports the pain is partially relieved with acetaminophen but aggravated with activity. Most days, he takes 1-2 ibuprofen twice a day for pain relief. Past medical history includes hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and osteopenia. He takes daily calcium and vitamin D supplementation, along with metformin and lisinopril. Physical examination and laboratory studies were normal during his annual visit 4 months ago. Vital signs at today’s visit show a temperature of 36.6°C (97.8°F), blood pressure of 148/82 mm Hg, pulse of 94/min, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. The patient appears well, with no lymphadenopathy, and normal cardiopulmonary, abdominal, and musculoskeletal examinations. Muscle strength is 5/5 in all extremities, and there is no reproducible spinal tenderness to palpation. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s current condition? 

 Laboratory value       Result     
 Hemoglobin      10.9 g/dL     
 Platelets      210,000/mm3     
 Leukocytes      13,000/mm3     
 Creatinine      2.2 mg/dL (previously 0.8 mg/dL)     
 Blood urea nitrogen      45 mg/dL     
 Calcium      10.8 mg/dL     
 Urinalysis      2+ protein, 1+ blood, few granular casts, light chains
questions.solution:
The patient presents with one month of back pain, elevated creatinine, hypercalcemia (calcium 10.8 mg/dL), anemia (hemoglobin 10.9 g/dL), proteinuria, granular casts, and light chains in the urine. This classic presentation indicates multiple myeloma, which is a plasma cell malignancy resulting in excessive production of monoclonal immunoglobulins. Light chain cast ոерthrοраthy can occur in patients with high rates of production and excretion of immunoglobulin-free light chains. Ligh chains are toxic to the tubules and can form obstructing tubular casts that lead to kidney damage (myeloma kidney) and acute kidney injury (AKI). Hypercalcemia can be seen due to increased bone resorption, and anemia is related to bone marrow infiltration by malignant plasma cells. This patient’s back pain could be caused by osteolytic bone lesions, which are common in multiple myeloma.       

Diagnostic workup for intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI) due to non-glomerular causes involves a focused history, physical examination, and laboratory testing. A basic metabolic panel will show elevated creatinine, and urinalysis with microscopy can reveal diagnostic features specific to each condition. For example, the urine in patients with acute tubular necrosis (ATN) is significant for muddy brown granular casts and fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) >2%. Patients with acute interstitial nephritis (AIN) will have pyuria, white blood cell casts, and eosinophilia, along with a history of medication exposure (e.g. antibiotics). The urinalysis in conditions that lead to intratubular obstruction (i.e., multiple myeloma, tumor lysis syndrome) will often reveal crystals or cast formation. In cases of extraglomerular vascular injury, such as renal artery stenosis or thrombotic microangiopathies, urinalysis will show hematuria and proteinuria, and there can be signs of systemic vascular compromise (e.g., hypertension, livedo reticularis).        

Option Analysis

❌ Ibuprofen toxicity:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can cause an acute kidney injury (AKI) through acute interstitial nephritis or reduced renal perfusion. However, this patient’s hypercalcemia, anemia, and proteinuria are not typical findings of NSAID-related AKIs. These findings, along with light chains in the urine, are consistent with multiple myeloma.
✅ Multiple myeloma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperparathyroidism:
NephrolithiasisHyperparathyroidism can cause hypercalcemia, but it would not explain this patient’s acute rise in creatinine, proteinuria, anemia, and light chains in the urine, which are more consistent with multiple myeloma. 
❌ Nephrolithiasis:
Incorrect: Kidney stones can cause hematuria and flank pain, but this patient has proteinuria, granular casts, and a systemic illness (anemia, hypercalcemia), suggestive of multiple myeloma.
❌ Vitamin D toxicity:
Incorrect: Vitamin D toxicity can cause hypercalcemia; however, it would not explain the findings of anemia, proteinuria, or acute kidney injury seen in this case, which are key features of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of fever, body aches, and watery diarrhea for the past three days. The patient returned home from East Asia four days ago where she was volunteering on a farm. She reports that she ate the local food and drank water from a tap. She does not recall a history of insect bites. She has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications. Temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. No rash is present. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination are within normal limits aside from increased bowel sounds. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient recently traveled to a rural area and consumed local tap water/food and presents with fever and gastrointestinal symptoms; she most likely has traveler's diarrhea. Most cases of traveler’s diarrhea are caused by bacterial entero-pathogens, and typically symptoms resolve with supportive care that may include antacids, bismuth-subsalicylate, and anti-diarrheal agents (e.g. loperamide).

All patients who are returning from travel with a fever should be presumed to have an endemic illness from the country where they traveled. They should have a targeted history and physical examination, which can often reveal clues as to the specific underlying disease process. Importantly, all patients should be screened for the presence of a rash (and its clinical characteristics, if present) which can further narrow the differential diagnosis, in addition to inquiring about associated risk factors (e.g. arthropod bite).

When a specific disease is suspected, further confirmatory testing can be performed via a variety of modalities, including nucleic amplification testing, serology, and stool/blood culture. However, traveler's diarrhea can be diagnosed clinically based on a history of travel, three or more unformed stools per 24 hours, and associated abdominal symptoms. Symptoms typically resolve in 4 to 5 days with supportive care.

Option Analysis

✅ Symptomatic management:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Stool culture:
Incorrect: A stool culture is not typically indicated for patients with suspected traveler's diarrhea. Management centers on symptomatic relief with anti-emetics, anti-pyretic agents, and anti-diarrheal agents.
❌ Stool ova and parasites:
Incorrect: Stool ova and parasites are not typically indicated for patients with suspected traveler's diarrhea unless symptoms fail to improve with conservative management strategies. Management should center on symptomatic relief with anti-emetics, anti-pyretic agents, and anti-diarrheal agents.
❌ Parasite nucleic amplification testing:
Incorrect: Parasite nucleic amplification testing should be considered when there is concern for malaria. This patient does not have a history of mosquito bites, making this diagnosis less likely.
❌ Viral nucleic amplification testing:
Incorrect: Viral nucleic amplification testing should be considered for patients when there is concern for Zika, yellow fever, Chikungunya, or Japanese encephalitis. This patient's presentation is consistent with uncomplicated traveler's diarrhea, and conservative management without testing is appropriate.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents to the clinic for a routine well-patient care visit. He has a history of hyperlipidemia and well-controlled hypertension. His medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. He has no history of smoking, alcohol use, or recreational drug use. He is physically active and follows a healthy diet. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in his father, who had a myocardial infarction at age 60. Blood pressure is 124/78 mmHg, heart rate is 68 beats/min, respiratory rate is 14 breaths/min, and BMI is 27 kg/m². Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations are normal. Neurological and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following tests is recommended for this patient?

choices.text: Low-dose computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A part of the well-patient care visit for this 49-year-old man should include recommending a screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer. Colorectal cancer is the third most common cancer and the second leading cause of cancer-related deaths in the United States. Screening is recommended for average-risk adults beginning at age 45 to detect precancerous polyps and early-stage cancer, which can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality.        

Several screening options are available, including colonoscopy, which is considered the gold standard due to its ability to visualize the entire colon and remove polyps during the procedure. Colonoscopy should be performed every 10 years in healthy patients with normal findings. Other options for colon cancer screening include stool-based tests (fecal occult blood test or fecal immunochemical test) which should be performed every 1 to 3 years. Computed tomography (CT) colonography (every 5 years) and flexible sigmoidoscopy (every 5 years) may also be used for colon cancer screening. Patients with a family history of colorectal cancer are considered at elevated risk, and screening may need to begin at an earlier age.   

Option Analysis

❌ Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) ultrasound:
Incorrect: This screening test is recommended for males aged 65 to 75 years who have a history of smoking. It is not indicated for asymptomatic males outside of this age range or in patients like this one without a smoking history.
✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prostate-specific antigen (PSA):
Incorrect: PSA screening for prostate cancer is typically recommended for people with prostates aged 50 to 69 using shared decision-making. While this patient is approaching the age range, routine PSA screening is not yet recommended for him based on age. 
❌ Low-dose computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest:
Incorrect: This screening is indicated for individuals aged 50 to 80 with a 20-pack-year smoking history who currently smoke or have quit within the last 15 years. The patient has no history of smoking, making lung cancer screening inappropriate. 
❌ Bone density scan:
Incorrect: Bone density testing (DEXA) is generally recommended for postmenopausal females or males over 50 with additional risk factors for osteoporosis. There is no indication for osteoporosis screening in this healthy 49-year-old man without risk factors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic to establish care. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. She does not have a history of tobacco, alcohol, or recreational substance use. Her diet consists of mostly fast food. She rarely exercises. Family history is significant for hypertension in her father and sister. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 80/minute, and respiratory rate is 16/minute. BMI is 21 kg/m2. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable. In addition to providing lifestyle counseling, which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Calculate her 10-year Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) risk

questions.solution:
This 45-year-old woman should have her 10-year Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) risk estimated using a calculator as part of the adult well-patient care visit. Cardiovascular disease is the most common cause of mortality worldwide. The ASCVD risk calculator incorporates age, blood pressure, cholesterol levels, smoking status, and diabetes to estimate the patient’s likelihood of a cardiovascular event within the next decade. The results of the risk assessment should be used to guide recommendations for statin therapy and lifestyle modifications to prevent cardiovascular disease.       

Patients at low risk (less than 5% risk) based on the ASCVD risk calculator should be counseled regarding regular ехеrcisе and a healthy diet. Patients who are at intermediate 10-year AЅCVD risk (7.5-20%) may require further risk stratification and may benefit from statin therapy and other primary prevention measures. Patients at high risk (greater than 20%) do not need additional risk stratification and should receive primary prevention interventions including intensive lifestyle changes and pharmacotherapy.    

Option Analysis

❌ Start aspirin 81 mg daily:
Incorrect: Aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease is recommended in select high-risk patients. Without first calculating this patient's ASCVD risk, starting aspirin could expose her to unnecessary bleeding risk without clear benefit.
✅ Calculate her 10-year Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) risk:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order coronary artery calcium (CAC) score:
Incorrect: A CAC score may help assess coronary artery disease risk in intermediate-risk patients, but the ASCVD risk should be calculated first to determine if this is necessary. CAC is often used when there is uncertainty after the ASCVD risk calculation.  
❌ Provide reassurance and schedule follow-up in 6 months :
Incorrect: Reassurance and delayed follow-up are not appropriate, as this patient should have age-appropriate screening for cardiovascular disease. Further evaluation with an ASCVD risk score will help determine if additional interventions are necessary.  
❌ Start atorvastatin  :
Incorrect: While statin therapy may be indicated depending on this patient's ASCVD risk, initiating statins without first assessing her risk score would be premature. The decision to start therapy should be individualized based on the patient’s calculation risk.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with four hours of suprapubic pressure and difficulty initiating urination. Medical history is significant only for seasonal allergies, which are currently managed with over-the-counter diphenhydramine. The patient does not drink alcohol or use tobacco products. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 160/87 mmHg, heart rate is 101 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Body mass index (BMI) is 35 kg/m². On physical examination, there is mild left costovertebral angle tenderness. The suprapubic region is soft without a palpable mass and shows only minimal tenderness on deep palpation. Cardiopulmonary and the remainder of the abdominal exam are unremarkable. Initial laboratory studies show a creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL (baseline 0.7 mg/dL). Which of the following additional tests is most likely to quickly delineate the anatomic region of pathology?

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of urinary retention in the setting of active diphenhydramine use, and laboratory studies confirm acute kidney injury (AKI). The next step in evaluating suspected postrenal AKI is to distinguish upper-tract from lower-tract obstruction. A bedside post-void residual (PVR) bladder scan rapidly confirms whether urine is being retained in the bladder, signifying a lower-tract process.

Acute kidney injury (AKI) refers to a sudden decline in kidney function that results in electrolyte imbalances, extracellular dysregulation, and accumulation of nitrogenous wastes such as ammonia and uric acid. It is diagnosed by a rise in serum creatinine, and urinalysis is typically used to screen for intrinsic renal disease, infection, or hematuria. Postrenal AKI results from urinary outflow obstruction, which increases intraluminal pressure and reduces glomerular filtration; classification as upper (ureteral) versus lower (bladder/urethral) obstruction helps narrow the differential.

Once postrenal AKI is suspected, a post-void residual (PVR) bladder scan quantifies the residual volume of urine and is a key fork in the diagnostic pathway. A PVR ≥100 mL indicates lower urinary tract obstruction and warrants immediate catheterization. Further imaging (e.g., ultrasound, CT) or cystoscopy may be indicated if a bladder outlet obstruction or urethral obstruction are suspected. History and physical examination may also reveal clues about the etiology in cases of benign prostatic hypertrophy, neurogenic bladder, or medication-induced urinary retention (e.g. use of medications with anticholinergic properties, such as diphenhydramine in this case). In contrast, a PVR <100 mL suggests an upper urinary tract etiology and should prompt CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis to identify nephrolithiasis, malignancy, or intrabdominal abscess.

Option Analysis

✅ Post-void residual bladder scan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: While a CT can identify many causes for urinary obstruction (e.g., ureteral stones, masses), it takes longer to obtain, costs more, exposes the patient to ionizing radiation, and may be unnecessary for cases of straightforward medication-induced urinary retention. As a result, a CT is typically reserved as a second‑line study, used only if additional information is needed after a quick post-void bladder scan has determined whether urinary retention is present.
❌ Serum blood urea nitrogen (BUN):
Incorrect: A serum BUN helps calculate the BUN:Creatinine ratio, but it does not localize an obstruction to the upper versus lower urinary tract, which is the main concern in this vignette. Instead, this can quickly and easily be determined with a post-void bladder scan.
❌ Urinalysis :
Incorrect: A urinalysis is useful in evaluating for the presence of infection, hematuria, proteinuria, or casts. However, it does not determine whether urinary obstruction is from an upper or a lower urinary tract process, which is the main concern in this vignette. Instead, this can quickly and easily be determined with a post-void bladder scan.
❌ Renal biopsy:
Incorrect: A renal biopsy is an invasive test reserved for the diagnosis of intrinsic kidney disease (e.g. glomerular disease). It does not determine whether urinary obstruction is from an upper or a lower urinary tract process. Instead, this can quickly and easily be determined with a post-void bladder scan.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for follow-up regarding a testicular mass. The patient noticed a small, painful lump on the right testicle one month ago. The patient’s father had testicular cancer at age 31. Three days ago, the patient underwent testicular ultrasound which showed a solid, right sided intratesticular mass. Serum studies, including complete blood count, human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) are pending. A chest X-ray and computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis did not reveal any additional lesions. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, there is a right-sided testicular mass that is tender to palpation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 29-year-old man recently presented with a painful testicular lump, and ultrasonography revealed a solid intratesticular mass. Considering this patient’s family history, this presentation is very concerning for testicular cancer. The best next step is to proceed with unilateral orchiectomy.

Testicular cancer most commonly presents individuals with male reproductive anatomy aged 15-34 years, and treatment options depend on the type of testicular cancer. The most common types include seminoma, non-seminoma, mixed germ cell tumor, and sex cord/stromal tumors. The initial diagnostic workup generally includes scrotal ultrasound, serum tumor markers (e.g., hCG, LDH, AFP), and additional imaging (e.g., CT of the abdomen and pelvis, chest X-ray) to assess disease extent.

All patients with suspected testicular malignancy should undergo orchiectomy with pathologic analysis rather than biopsy due to the risk of hematogenous seeding. Patients should be counseled on the potential risks of infertility and hypogonadism, and sperm banking for future family planning should be discussed. Urology and oncology consultations will help guide subsequent treatment planning and recommendations, which may include retroperitoneal lymph node dissection, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and/or active surveillance, depending on the type and extent of disease.

Option Analysis

✅ Orchiectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Retroperitoneal lymph node dissection:
Incorrect: This option may be indicated depending upon the staging of the suspected testicular malignancy. However, final management cannot be determined until pathology results from the removed testicle are reviewed.
❌ Testicular biopsy:
Incorrect: When testicular cancer is suspected, orchiectomy should be performed instead of biopsy. Biopsy carries a theoretical risk of hematogenous seeding of the tumor.
❌ Localized radiation therapy:
Incorrect: Radiation may be indicated depending upon the type and stage of the suspected testicular malignancy. However, it cannot be initiated before pathology results from orchiectomy are available for staging and treatment planning.
❌ Intravenous chemotherapy:
Incorrect: Chemotherapy may be indicated depending on the type and stage of the suspected testicular malignancy. However, it cannot be initiated before pathology results from orchiectomy are available for staging and treatment planning.

questions.text:
A 94-year-old man presents to the primary care physician for a routine evaluation accompanied by his son. He has no medical concerns and feels well, though he reports decreased urine output over the past 2 days. The patient was recently seen in the emergency department for a fall and closed head injury but has otherwise been living independently. He has a past medical history of hypertension, high cholesterol, and dementia. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 136/64 mmHg, heart rate is 77 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is in no acute distress. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examination are within normal limits. Mucous membranes appear dry. The patient is alert and oriented to self and place, which is the patient's baseline. Laboratory results are displayed below. Which of the following is most likely to be found on further history?  

 Laboratory value Result
 Serum chemistry
 Sodium 151 mEq/L
 Potassium 4.8 mEq/L
 Chloride 97 mEq/L
 Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL

choices.text: Surgical correction of an obstructive uropathy

questions.solution:
This patient presents with asymptomatic hypernatremia, associated with decreased urine output and dry mucous membranes, suggestive of hypovolemic hyponatremia. In the older adult population, this condition is often secondary to inadequate fluid intake due to impaired thirst mechanisms or limited access to water.

Hypernatremia is an electrolyte imbalance where serum sodium concentration exceeds 145 milliequivalents per liter (mEq/L). It can be classified based on onset (acute or chronic) and volume status (hypovolemic, euvolemic, or hypervolemic).

Historical factors associated with hypernatremia depend on the underlying cause. For example, patients with hypovolemic hyponatremia may report a history suggestive of volume losses, recent diuretic use, or inadequate fluid intake. Clinical findings of volume depletion, such as dry mucous membranes or orthostatic hypotension, may be present. Those with euvolemic hypernatremia may report polydipsia or polyuria and will generally appear hydrated on examination. Patients with hypervolemic hypernatremia will have signs of volume overload, such as shortness of breath and peripheral edema.

Option Analysis

✅ Low fluid intake:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent hypertonic saline administration:
Incorrect: Hypertonic saline is typically used to treat acute, severe hyponatremia and would most likely result in a rapid and significant increase in serum sodium. This would typically present with severe neurological symptoms, such as seizure or coma. This patient is currently asymptomatic.
❌ Recent furosemide use:
Incorrect: Furosemide, a loop diuretic, can cause dehydration and subsequent hypernatremia; however, it is more likely to result in increased urine output (polyuria) rather than decreased urine output (oliguria), as observed in this patient.
❌ Recent mannitol administration:
Incorrect: Mannitol, an osmotic diuretic, can raise serum sodium levels. However, it is typically associated with increased urine output (polyuria), not decreased urine output (oliguria).
❌ Surgical correction of an obstructive uropathy:
Incorrect: Surgical correction of obstructive uropathy can result in post-obstructive diuresis and hypernatremia. However, this patient does not have a history of prostate disease or any symptoms indicative of obstructive uropathy. Additionally, the patient has experienced a decrease in urine output, not an increase.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a history of moderate-to-severe ulcerative colitis presents to the emergency department due to a three day history of severe diffuse abdominal pain and six episodes of bloody diarrhea daily. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 37.8 °C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 98/76 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% of room air. The patient appears ill and dehydrated. Abdominal examination is notable for diffuse abdominal tenderness on palpation without guarding, rebound, or rigidity. Digital rectal exam is significant for bright red blood. Laboratory results are significant for a hemoglobin of 8.5 g/dL, thrombocytosis, and an elevated CRP. Stool studies are sent for infectious etiologies including C. difficile. Abdominal x-ray is significant for colonic wall thickening and loss of haustrations. There is no colonic dilatation seen on imaging. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer IV fluids, IV antibiotics, IV glucocorticoids, and transfuse-packed red blood cells
Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent colectomy
Administer IV fluids and refer for an urgent colonoscopy
Administer high-dose oral glucocorticoids and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks
Administer 5-aminosalicylic acid enema and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks.

questions.solution:
This patient has a three day history of severe diffuse abdominal pain and six episodes of loose bloody stools daily, current presentation of shock (e.g., tachycardia, and hypotension), along with physical examination significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness and laboratory findings significant for anemia and elevated markers of inflammation (elevated CRP, thrombocytosis). Together, these findings suggest an episode of acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC) complicated by hemodynamic instability and hypovolemic shock due to blood loss.    

Acute severe UC is a potentially life-threatening condition as it can be complicated by bowel perforation, toxic megacolon, or severe refractory hemorrhage unresponsive to treatment. The initial management of a hemodynamically unstable patient with suspected severe acute UC consists of stabilization with IV fluids and possible blood products in the case of hypovolemic shock due to hemorrhage, initiation of IV antibiotics in the presence of fever and systemic toxicity, and administration of IV glucocorticoids.    

Emergency surgery would be indicated in the case of acute severe UC complicated by toxic megacolon evidenced by the presence of colonic dilation on abdominal imaging, perforation evidenced by pneumoperitoneum on abdominal imaging, and massive refractory rectal bleeding unresponsive to resuscitation. Urgent surgery would be indicated in the case of acute severe UC unresponsive to medical treatment.    

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV fluids, IV antibiotics, IV glucocorticoids, and transfuse-packed red blood cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV fluids and refer for urgent colectomy  :
Incorrect: Toxic megacolon is a complication of a severe flare of ulcerative colitis, characterized by acute dilation of the colon and signs of systemic toxicity such as fever, tachycardia, hypotension, and altered mental status. It can be diagnosed in the appropriate clinical situation when the colon is dilated to a diameter of more than 6 cm on imaging studies. This patient does not have colonic dilatation on radiography.  
❌ Administer IV fluids and refer for an urgent colonoscopy  :
Incorrect: Although IV fluids are essential for managing hemodynamically unstable patients with suspected acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC), colonoscopy is contraindicated due to the increased risk of perforation.  
❌ Administer high-dose oral glucocorticoids and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks  :
Incorrect: This patient is hemodynamically unstable with likely acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC), and therefore, discharging the patient would be inappropriate.  
❌ Administer 5-aminosalicylic acid enema and discharge home with a follow-up in 2 weeks.  :
Incorrect:  This patient is hemodynamically unstable with likely acute severe ulcerative colitis (UC), and therefore, discharging the patient would be inappropriate.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with a 2-month history of bloody diarrhea, LLQ abdominal pain, and fecal urgency. She has no past medical history and is currently not taking any medications. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 5 years. Family history is notable for a parent diagnosed with irritable bowel syndrome. Vitals are within normal range. Physical examination is significant for mild left lower quadrant abdominal tenderness on palpation without rebound or guarding. Laboratory evaluation is significant for a hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL. Fecal occult blood test is positive. Stool studies are negative for infectious etiologies. Fecal calprotectin is positive. Which of the following additional physical exam findings would most likely be present?
questions.solution:
This patient has a 2-month history of bloody diarrhea, LLQ abdominal pain, and fecal urgency. These symptoms are typical of ulcerative colitis. Laboratory evaluation shows mild anemia, a positive fecal occult blood test (FOBT), and a positive fecal calprotectin. These findings are most concerning for ulcerative colitis, which is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon, causing continuous ulcerations of the mucosa and submucosa. It has a bimodal pattern of incidence according to age with two peaks: the first between the ages of 15 and 30, and the second between the ages of 50 and 70.   

History typically reveals bloody diarrhea, diffuse or periumbilical crampy abdominal pain, tenesmus, and fecal urgency. Some patients may report extraintestinal symptoms, like eye pain and redness, joint pain and swelling, and rashes. Physical examination typically reveals abdominal tenderness to palpation. Rectal exam might reveal bright red blood and discomfort on palpation. Additionally, there might be extra-intestinal findings involving the eyes (e.g., uveitis, episcleritis), the skin (e.g., erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), and the hepatobiliary system (e.g., jaundice due to primary sclerosing cholangitis).  

Erythema nodosum is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction that causes acute panniculitis and manifests as raised, tender, erythematous nodules or plaques on the lower extremities, most commonly on the shins. It is associated with inflammatory bowel disease, infections (e.g., Streptococcus, Tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis), sarcoidosis, and medications (e.g., antibiotics, oral contraceptives). It is the most common dermatologic manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease, and its appearance coincides with intestinal activity.  


Option Analysis

✅ Erythema nodosum  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perianal skin tags  :
Incorrect:  Perianal skin tags, which appear as pedunculated lesions on a narrow stalk in the anal region, can be found in Crohn disease. Although Crohn disease can present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and positive fecal calprotectin, gross blood may or may not be seen in the stool. Patients with Crohn disease typically have right sided abdominal pain, fatigue, and diarrhea that may or may not be bloody as their main symptoms.  
❌ Ecthyma gangrenosum  :
Incorrect:  Ecthyma gangrenosum is a severe life-threatening, rapidly progressive painless gangrenous ulcer that may present in immunocompromised patients with Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia/sepsis. It may be confused with pyoderma gangrenosum, which is a dermatologic manifestation of ulcerative colitis.    
❌ Swan neck deformity  :
Incorrect:  Swan neck deformity, which is characterized by the hyperextension of PIP joints and flexion of DIP joints of the hands, is a finding seen in rheumatoid arthritis. Inflammatory bowel disease-associated arthritis/arthropathy typically involves the large joints or the spine and hips when ankylosing spondylitis is present.  
❌ Dermatitis herpetiformis  :
Incorrect:  Dermatitis herpetiformis, which is characterized by the presence of intensely pruritic inflammatory papules and vesicles on the forearms, knees, and buttocks, is a manifestation of gluten sensitivity and celiac disease. It is not associated with ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of diarrhea and low-grade fevers over the past several weeks. The patient has been having 3-4 episodes of bloody diarrhea almost every day. Abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea have persisted despite eliminating dairy and gluten products from his diet. The diarrhea is preceded by intense cramping abdominal pain that is relieved with bowel movements. In addition, the patient has measured oral temperatures up to 100.4°F at home. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation throughout the abdomen. Rectal examination shows perianal skin tags. Serum transaminases and bilirubin are normal. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a condition characterized by chronic gastrointestinal tract inflammation that can be subdivided into Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis (UC). Crohn disease can affect any part of the GI tract (from the mouth to the anus) and is characterized by transmural skip lesions which can lead to abdominal pain, diarrhea, fatigue, and fever.  

History in patients with Crohn disease typically demonstrates postprandial abdominal pain – usually in the right lower quadrant – and often non-bloody diarrhea. However, if the disease is in the colon, the patient might report bloody diarrhea. Additionally, many patients report fatigue, weight loss, and fever. History and physical exam should look for extraintestinal manifestations such as joint pain, eye pain and redness, and skin findings such as erythematous, raised, tender lesions on the lower extremities consistent with erythema nodosum. Painful ulcerations known as pyoderma gangrenosum can also be seen in patients with inflammatory bowel disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Erythema nodosum   :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Dermatitis herpetiformis   :
Incorrect: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease. Although celiac disease and inflammatory bowel disease may present similarly, there are a few key distinctions in this patient: bloody diarrhea and perianal skin tags are associated with Crohn disease and not Celiac. In addition, dermatitis herpetiformis usually resolves when patients with celiac disease completely eliminate gluten; this patient’s symptoms have persisted despite eliminating gluten.   
❌ Widespread skin excoriations   :
Incorrect: Conditions that result in elevated bilirubin can lead to pruritus and subsequent excoriations. Crohn disease is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, which can present with elevated bilirubin, hepatomegaly, and eventually cirrhosis. However, this patient’s bilirubin is normal, and therefore pruritus and excoriations would not be expected.   
❌ Murphy sign   :
Incorrect: Murphy sign, or pain and discomfort in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration when the examiner’s hands palpate below the liver edge, is an indication of acute cholecystitis. This patient’s diarrhea, fever, and perianal skin tags are more consistent with Crohn disease.
❌ Hyporeflexia of bilateral lower extremities   :
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome can present as lower extremity weakness or paralysis which is often preceded by a respiratory or gastrointestinal viral illness. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease – specifically, Crohn disease with bloody diarrhea, perianal skin tags, and fever.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a right femoral neck fracture after a fall. The patient is intubated, given general anesthesia, and taken to the operating room for an open reduction and internal fixation. The surgery course is unremarkable. He is extubated without incident and sent to the hospital’s surgical floor. Three days later, he develops shortness of breath and a productive cough. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 122/85 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, and oxygen saturation is 85% on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds at the left lung base. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with shortness of breath, cough, hypoxia, and decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. In combination, these findings are concerning for pneumonia.

Pneumonia can be categorized based on the site of acquisition. If the pneumonia is acquired outside the hospital setting, it is classified as community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). If the patient has been hospitalized ≥ 48 hours, it is hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), and if the patient has required mechanical ventilation for ≥ 48 hours, it is considered ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). This classification system exists so clinicians can gauge the patient’s risk for exposure to antibiotic-resistant organisms and prescribe appropriate antimicrobial therapy. Given that this patient has been in the hospital for several days, his condition would be classified as HAP.

The next step in the diagnosis and management of HAP depends on the patient’s clinical status. Airway, breathing, and circulation should be assessed and abnormalities addressed expediently. In this case, the patient is in respiratory distress, as evidenced by tachypnea and hypoxia. Acute interventions should be performed to prevent sequelae of hypoxemia. For instance, supplemental oxygen can be administered to increase the patient’s oxygen saturation. Additional forms of acute management include continuous monitoring of heart rate, blood pressure, and oxygen saturation.

Once the patient’s respiratory status is stabilized, it would then be appropriate to continue the diagnostic workup with a chest radiograph, laboratory studies (e.g., CBC, procalcitonin), blood cultures, and sputum samples. Antimicrobial therapy should be based on an assessment of the patient’s risk for multidrug-resistant (MDR) organisms, such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. Antibiotics should also cover a wide range of pathogens that can be encountered in the hospital setting, including methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumonia, Enterobacter, Acinetobacter, and Streptococcus species.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supplemental oxygen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination findings are concerning for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). A chest radiograph is useful in the diagnosis of HAP. However, it is important to first address the patient’s respiratory distress and decreased oxygen saturation.  
❌ Cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination findings are concerning for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). Cefepime is a reasonable antibiotic option for the treatment of HAP. However, it is important to first address the patient’s respiratory distress and decreased oxygen saturation.  
❌ Blood cultures:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination are concerning for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). Blood cultures are an important part of the workup. However, it is important to first address the patient’s respiratory distress and decreased oxygen saturation.  
❌ Repeat vitals in 1 hour:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and physical examination findings are concerning for hospital-acquired pneumonia. Since current vitals already demonstrate hypoxemia, the patient must be provided supplemental oxygen without delay.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for fractures of the left, 5th and 6th ribs after a fall at home. The fractures are minimally displaced and no surgical intervention is performed. The patient is provided with pain control and encouraged to use an incentive spirometer. On the third day of hospitalization, the patient becomes short of breath, febrile, and develops a nonproductive cough. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg, pulse is 105/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. She is placed on 2L oxygen via nasal cannula. On physical examination, she appears ill, has labored breathing, and has rales in the left lower lung field. There is tenderness over the left 5th and 6th ribs, but the surrounding skin is unremarkable. She has no lower extremity swelling. Relevant laboratory studies are obtained and results are shown below. Chest x-ray demonstrates a new left lower lobe consolidation. What is the best next step in the diagnostic workup?
 
Laboratory Value   
Result
Leukocyte count
15000/mm3   
Neutrophils, segmented
78%
Neutrophils, banded
5%  
Procalcitonin
0.75 ng/mL  
D-dimer
< 500 ng/mL
questions.solution:
This patient has developed pneumonia during her hospital stay, as evidenced by the physical examination findings and chest x-ray demonstrating a new left lower lobe consolidation. Since the patient has been hospitalized for over 48 hours, her condition would be classified as hospital-associated pneumonia (HAP).

The next steps in diagnostic workup include obtaining blood cultures and induced sputum samples for Gram staining, culture, and sensitivity testing. These tests may potentially identify the causative pathogen(s), which can assist in tailoring antibiotic therapy. Induced sputum is a non-invasive method whereby the patient inhales a hypertonic saline solution to trigger a coughing response. The aim is to obtain a sample of respiratory secretions from the lower respiratory tract, which improves the diagnostic yield. This technique contrasts with obtaining samples from a spontaneous cough, where sputum samples may be difficult to obtain or contaminated with oral flora.

In contrast, patients diagnosed with ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) cannot undergo this technique because they are intubated. For these patients, bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) or mini-BAL are preferred. In both techniques, samples from the lower respiratory tract are obtained for Gram staining and culture.  

Option Analysis

❌ Point-of-care ultrasonography:
Incorrect: The patient’s clinical history, physical examination, laboratory studies, and imaging findings are concerning for hospital-acquired pneumonia. A chest x-ray has already demonstrated a left lower lobe consolidation consistent with this diagnosis. As a result, further imaging is not necessary at this time. Of note, point-of-care ultrasonography may be performed to diagnose ventilator-associated pneumonia since these patients may not be amenable to transport for imaging.  
✅ Induced sputum sample:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diagnostic thoracentesis:
Incorrect: The patient’s clinical history, physical examination, laboratory studies, and imaging findings are concerning for hospital-acquired pneumonia. Diagnostic thoracentesis would be indicated for a pleural effusion of more than minimal size, complex pleural effusion, or concern for empyema. However, in this patient’s case, the chest x-ray does not demonstrate a pleural effusion.  
❌ Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage:
Incorrect: This patient likely has hospital-acquired pneumonia. Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage may be used in cases of pneumonia when induced sputum samples cannot be obtained (such as in mechanically ventilated patients) or for severe or persistent pneumonia with nondiagnostic sputum samples. However, in this patient’s case, an induced sputum sample would be the most appropriate next step.  
❌ Mini-bronchoalveolar lavage:
Incorrect: This patient likely has hospital-acquired pneumonia. Mini-bronchoalveolar lavage (mini-BAL) is a way to obtain a sputum sample for Gram stain and culture. However, this technique is generally more appropriate for mechanically ventilated patients who are unable to provide an induced sputum sample.

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents to the emergency department for shortness of breath, which started one day ago and has progressively worsened. He also has a productive cough. Medical history includes cirrhosis and congestive heart failure. Temperature is 39 °C (103.1 °F), blood pressure is 112/67 mmHg, pulse is 130/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and room air oxygen saturation is 93%. There are decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung. The patient appears jaundiced and has prominent paraumbilical veins. A chest radiograph demonstrates a dense opacity in the left lower lobe. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough. Physical examination shows decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe and a chest radiograph demonstrates a left lower lobe opacification. In combination, these findings are highly suggestive of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP).

Once a diagnosis of CAP has been made, its severity should be determined to help decide if the patient should be treated as an outpatient or inpatient based on their risk of morbidity and mortality. One system for classifying severity is the pneumonia severity index (PSI), which is outlined in the table below. PSI categorizes patients into 5 classes based on clinical elements, laboratory elements, and radiographic elements.
