Temperature is 37.2C (98.9F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals a friction rub over the left sternal border. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The patient is treated with aspirin, resulting in significant relief of his symptoms. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of pleuritic chest pain following a recent myocardial infarction is suggestive of post-myocardial infarction pericarditis. Although most patients improve with supportive measures, patients with persistent symptoms can be managed with aspirin and colchicine.  

Aspirin (acetylsalicylic acid) works by irreversibly inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2 (via acetylation).  This is in contrast to reversible COX inhibitors (non-aspirin NSAIDs) which can be further subdivided into 2 groups: non-selective COX inhibitors (e.g. ibuprofen), and selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g. celecoxib).  

Once absorbed, aspirin irreversibly inhibits COX-1 in platelets via covalent acetylation, decreasing the production of thromboxane A2–making it useful as an antiplatelet medication. Since aspirin irreversibly prevents the platelets from synthesizing new COX-1 enzymes, its effects persist until new platelets are produced. Ultimately, this is reflected in an increased bleeding time without affecting the prothrombin time (PT) or partial thromboplastin time (PTT). In addition, aspirin exerts additional antiinflammatory effects in the liver–resulting in decreased production of pro-inflammatory prostaglandin production.  



Option Analysis

✅ Irreversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phosphodiesterase III inhibitor:
Incorrect: Phosphodiesterase inhibitors break down cAMP in platelets and promote platelet aggregation. Phosphodiesterase inhibitors such as cilostazol and dipyridamole are antiplatelet agents used in the treatment of claudication, stroke prophylaxis and stable angina. They are not effective in the management of post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.
❌ Vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Warfarin serves as a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor used for chronic anticoagulation. It is not used to relieve chest pain associated with post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.
❌ Reversible inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Incorrect: Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as diclofenac and ibuprofen are reversible cyclooxygenase inhibitors. 
❌ Xanthine oxidase inhibitor:
Incorrect: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor and used in the management of chronic gout. It does not relieve chest pain associated with post-myocardial infarction pericarditis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset severe right foot pain associated with swelling and redness. The patient does not report any history of recent trauma. The patient has not experienced similar symptoms before. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows redness, and warmth over the right great toe. A sample of synovial fluid shows needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Recommend an increase in organ-rich foods

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute toe pain and associated erythema and swelling. These findings, in conjunction with needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy, is consistent with an acute gout flare secondary to monosodium urate deposition in the joint space.  

The preferred first-line agent for acute gout flares is non-selective cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibitors such as naproxen, ibuprofen or ketorolac, which reversibly inhibit both COX-1 and COX-2; thereby, decreasing prostaglandin and thromboxane synthesis.    

Non-selective COX inhibitors  may be used for managing post-operative pain, dysmenorrhea, headache, and patent ductus arteriosus in premature infants (indomethacin). These medications can be taken perorally, but ketorolac, ibuprofen, and indomethacin are the only NSAIDs that are also available in parenteral form. Nonselective COX inhibitors reduce polyp formation in patients with primary familial adenomatous polyposis.  

Common adverse effects include gastritis, gastric/duodenal ulcers or bleeding.  There is a risk of kidney injury with the use of any NSAIDs, especially in patients with preexisting renal disease. Chronic abuse of NSAIDs can lead to analgesic nephropathy, which can manifest as chronic nephritis or renal papillary necrosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Administer allopurinol:
Incorrect: Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is indicated in patients with recurrent gout attacks. It is not effective for acute gout flares.
❌ Administer aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin should be avoided in patients with a history of gout as it competes with uric acid for excretion. It plays no role in the treatment of an acute gout attack.
❌ Recommend an increase in organ-rich foods:
Incorrect: Organ-rich foods, such as liver, often result in an increased production of uric acid. Increasing its consumption can precipitate an acute gout attack.
❌ Admit the patient for debridement:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is consistent with an acute gout attack which can be managed by administration of an anti-inflammatory agent. Debridement is not required in these patients.  
✅ Administer oral naproxen:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents for evaluation of joint pain, which has been ongoing for the past 4-months. The patient also noticed that she is sweating more excessively and her voice has gotten deeper. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 152/80 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals frontal bossing, protrusion of the jaw, and multiple skin tags on the patient’s back. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Oral glucose fails to suppress growth hormone levels. Head CT confirms a pituitary mass. The patient declines surgical intervention and is started on pegvisomant. Which of the following is expected to be seen in this patient as a result of this medication?

Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
12.8 g/dL
Hematocrit
45%
Blood glucose
180 mg/dL
IGF-1
Elevated
Growth hormone
Elevated

choices.text: Decreased insulin like growth factor-1 levels.
Increased insulin like growth factor levels.

questions.solution:
This patient has physical examination, imaging, and laboratory findings consistent with acromegaly. Most cases of acromegaly are due to growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas. The first-line treatment option is transsphenoidal resection of the adenoma, which has excellent outcomes in controlling the disease and normalizing growth hormone (GH) levels. However, medical treatment is available for patients who are poor fit for surgery, refuse surgery, or have an unresectable adenoma. The options of medical treatment for acromegaly include:  

  • Somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide, lanreotide): Somatostatin analogs are effective in the treatment of acromegaly. These agents inhibit growth hormone secretion, thus controlling the symptoms and complications of excessive growth hormone. Furthermore, somatostatin analogs have been shown to induce shrinkage of pituitary adenomas. Side effects of this drug class include bloating, loose stools, fat malabsorption. In addition, there is increased risk of gallstones due to gallbladder hypomotility.  

  • GH-receptor antagonist (e.g. pegvisomant): Pegvisomant is a newly developed medication that has been shown to be efficacious in treating acromegaly. It binds to GH receptors and prevents their activation. Also, as it blocks GH receptors in hepatocytes, it prevents the production of IGF-1. Since pegvisomant does not suppress GH hormone production, a minority of patients may experience an increase in the size of the adenoma due to increased GH production. It can rarely cause increased liver enzymes, which usually normalizes after stopping the medication. 

  • Dopamine agonists (e.g. cabergoline): Dopamine agonists have been shown to decrease growth hormone secretion from pituitary adenomas. It can be used alone or in combination with somatostatin analogs. Side effects include nausea, lightheadedness, depression and constipation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Decreased insulin like growth factor-1 levels.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Decreased growth hormone levels  :
Incorrect: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist that leads to decreased insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels. The decrease in IGF-1 levels leads to a loss of negative feedback, resulting in an increase in pituitary growth hormone production.
❌ Decreased adenoma size  :
Incorrect: Adenoma size decreases in patients who are taking somatostatin analogs (e.g. octreotide) or undergoing radiation therapy. In contrast, this patient is started on pegvisomant, which is a growth hormone receptor antagonist that leads to decreased insulin growth factor-1 (IGF-1) production. The decrease in IGF-1 levels leads to a loss of negative feedback, resulting in an increase in pituitary growth hormone production and pituitary size.  
❌ Increased insulin like growth factor levels.  :
Incorrect: Pegvisomant is a growth hormone (GH) receptor antagonist. Therefore, it blocks the binding of GH to hepatocytes and results in decreased insulin like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) production.   
❌ Increased blood glucose levels  :
Incorrect: Growth hormone (GH) is a diabetogenic hormone that causes insulin resistance and increased blood glucose levels. Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist that results in decreased blood glucose levels.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical examination. The patient has left hip pain, attributed to Paget disease of the bone diagnosed three years ago. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. The patient is allergic to penicillin. Her last menstrual period was ten years ago. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is given the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and shingles vaccine. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7. The patient inquires about a new PTH-analogue, teriparatide. Which of the following is a contraindication to this medication in this patient?

choices.text: Personal history of Paget disease of the bone

questions.solution:
This patient’s DEXA scan reveals a T-score of -2.7, which is consistent with a diagnosis of osteoporosis. Teriparatide is an effective treatment option for postmenopausal osteoporosis. It is, however, contraindicated in this patient given her history of Paget disease of the bone.  

Teriparatide is a recombinant analog of the parathyroid hormone given subcutaneously once per day. When given in a pulsatile fashion, it works by stimulating osteoblasts and reducing their apoptosis, resulting in a net increase in bone formation.    

Common side effects include transient hypercalcemia and an increased risk of developing osteosarcoma. The medication should be avoided when the patient has other diseases that also increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma, such as those with Paget disease of bone.  




Option Analysis

❌ Family history of breast cancer:
Incorrect: Family history of breast cancer is not a contraindication to teriparatide.  
✅ Personal history of Paget disease of the bone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent pneumococcal vaccine administration:
Incorrect: Interaction between a vaccine and a drug has been reported only with the influenza vaccine and four drugs, which are aminopyrine, phenytoin sodium, theophylline, and warfarin sodium. The pneumococcal vaccine does not interact with teriparatide.  
❌ Penicillin allergy:
Incorrect: There is no cross-reactivity between penicillin and teriparatide.  
❌ Postmenopausal state:
Incorrect: Teriparatide is a suitable medication for treating postmenopausal osteoporosis. The medication can be safely administered to women in a postmenopausal state.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left lower extremity pain and swelling. The patient was outside jogging when he suddenly felt a “pop” with associated pain behind the left knee. The left lower extremity has become progressively more swollen and painful over the past few hours. The patient recently traveled to the United States from London. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. Vital signs are within normal limits. Bilateral lower extremity pulses are normal and equal. Physical examination reveals a swollen and tender calf and ecchymosis at the popliteal region. Anterior and posterior drawer tests are negative. An ultrasound of the left calf is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset of pain and swelling of the calf after jogging. Ultrasound reveals a hypoechoic fluid collection. These findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal (Baker) cyst.

Popliteal cysts are common and reflect an enlargement of the gastrocnemius-semimembranosus bursa that extends into the adjacent knee joint space. Popliteal cysts are commonly associated with osteoarthritis, inflammatory arthritis, and a history of knee trauma (e.g. meniscus tears). They are typically asymptomatic unless rupture occurs.

Clinically, a popliteal cyst often presents as a swollen mass on the posterior aspect of the knee that can cause knee stiffness and difficulty with range of motion during exercise. Occasionally, popliteal cysts can rupture, causing acute pain and swelling of the calf that can mimic deep vein thrombosis. Management of a ruptured popliteal cyst should include ruling out a deep venous thrombosis. The fluid from a ruptured popliteal cyst will gradually be reabsorbed, therefore treatment is typically pain management, rest, and elevation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ruptured popliteal cyst:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Deep vein thrombosis:
Incorrect: While this patient has recently been on a long-distance flight, his physical examination and ultrasound findings are consistent with a ruptured popliteal cyst. Ultrasound findings associated with a deep vein thrombosis include an incompressible vein and the absence of Doppler flow if the vessel is completely occluded.  
❌ Lymphedema:
Incorrect: Lymphedema often presents as chronic swelling and induration of the lower extremities due to cardiovascular disease, previous radiation, malignancy, infection, or trauma.  
❌ Femoral artery occlusion:
Incorrect: Femoral artery occlusion will often manifest with a pulseless lower extremity with associated acute pain and swelling. Risk factors include atrial fibrillation and thrombophilia.  
❌ Posterior cruciate ligament tear:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament tears are associated with positive posterior drawer testing. This finding is not present in this patient.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe palpitations, dyspnea, restlessness, and fever. She also reports intermittent episodes of diarrhea over the past 2 days. She has a history of Graves' disease but has been taking her prescribed methimazole inconsistently. Temperature is 39.6°C (103.2°F), pulse is 150/min and irregular, blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. She appears agitated and diaphoretic on examination. Her skin is warm and moist to the touch, and she has an enlarged, non-tender thyroid gland. Neurological examination shows the presence of fine tremors and hyperreflexia. Laboratory studies reveal decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), increased free thyroxine (T4), and increased triiodothyronine (T3). An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Intravenous fluids are initiated. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe palpitations, restlessness, and fever, accompanied by signs of hyperthyroidism and laboratory findings of decreased TSH and increased T4 and T3 levels. These findings, along with her history of Graves' disease and medication noncompliance, are consistent with the diagnosis of thyroid storm, which is a severe, life-threatening form of thyrotoxicosis. Given this patient’s dyspnea and tachypnea secondary to atrial fibrillation, the best next step in management is to stabilize this patient by giving propranolol (non-selective beta-blocker).

Presenting symptoms of thyroid storm often include a severe increase in metabolic activity, leading to agitation, fever, tachycardia, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea. In addition, elevated thyroid hormone levels may result in a hyperadrenergic state, characterized by palpitations, tremors, and hyperreflexia.

The acute management of thyroid storm aims to control the adrenergic symptoms (beta blocker), inhibit new thyroid hormone synthesis (thionamide), block the release of preformed thyroid hormone (iodine), and prevent the peripheral conversion of thyroxine (T4) to the more potent triiodothyronine (T3) (glucocorticoids). These can be achieved by a combination of propranolol or other beta-blockers, propylthiouracil, and prednisolone or other glucocorticoids, followed by potassium iodide one hour after the administration of a thionamide. Surgery is reserved for patients with contraindications to thioamides who require urgent correction of hyperthyroidism.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of propranolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of iodine solution:
Incorrect: Iodine is used to block the release of preformed thyroid hormone and is typically administered one hour after administration of a thionamide. Controlling the adrenergic signs and symptoms including arrhythmia with propranolol is the first step in management.  
❌ Emergent thyroidectomy:
Incorrect: Surgery is not the first-line treatment for thyroid storm and is typically reserved for patients with contraindications to thioamides who require urgent correction of hyperthyroidism.  
❌ Administration of amiodarone:
Incorrect: While amiodarone can manage arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation, it can potentially exacerbate thyroid dysfunction due to its high iodine content.  
❌ Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are not indicated unless there's a suspicion of a precipitating infection. This patient's symptoms are more likely due to thyroid storm from medication non-compliance than to infection.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 1-month history of low-grade fever, unintentional weight loss of 3 kg (6.6 lbs), and a productive cough. Past medical history is significant for dementia. The patient lives in a nursing home. Temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination is significant for decreased breath sounds along with rhonchi over her right upper lung field. Chest x-ray is significant for an upper right lobe infiltrate and hilar lymphadenopathy. Sputum acid-fast bacillus smear and the nucleic acid amplification test are positive for Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Sputum sample is taken for culture and drug susceptibility testing. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient who resides in a nursing home, presents with a productive cough, constitutional symptoms, right upper lobe infiltrate, and hilar lymphadenopathy. These findings are suggestive of the diagnosis of active pulmonary tuberculosis disease, which is confirmed with a positive AFB smear and NAAT test.     

For patients with active tuberculosis, initial treatment consists of a 4-drug regimen of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for 2 months (intensive phase), followed by isoniazid and rifampin for an additional 4 months (continuation phase). In addition to initiating the 4-drug regimen, drug susceptibility testing should be performed on cultures to tailor the regimen and guide treatment during the continuation phase. If resistance to isoniazid is found, then the isoniazid should be switched to a fluoroquinolone, while resistance to rifampin or to both rifampin and isoniazid (indicating multi-drug resistant TB) necessitates the usage of a combination of bedaquiline, pretomanid, linezolid, and a fluoroquinolone for six months. For extensively drug-resistant TB, a long-term, individualized treatment plan is needed.  

In the United States, TB is a nationally notifiable disease, therefore cases need to be reported to a public health office. Incomplete treatment of pulmonary TB, typically from nonadherence, can lead to continued transmission and the development of drug-resistant TB in the community. Therefore, patients should be closely monitored during their treatment. Most states have laws authorizing public health officials to enforce disease control measures. One of these is Directly Observed Therapy (DOT), which is when a healthcare provider observes the patient taking each dose of antituberculosis medication to ensure adherence. This can be used in certain situations like when a patient has a history of drug treatment failure, previous nonadherence, or mental, emotional, or physical disabilities.  



Option Analysis

✅ Isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rifampin monotherapy:
Incorrect: Rifampin monotherapy is not appropriate for active tuberculosis due to the high risk of drug resistance.  
❌ Levofloxacin monotherapy:
Incorrect:  Levofloxacin monotherapy is not a first-line treatment for tuberculosis. It may be used as a component in a 4-drug regimen in the case of resistance or intolerance to first-line agents.  
❌ Isoniazid and rifampin:
Incorrect:  Isoniazid and rifampin are part of the continuation phase of tuberculosis treatment. These medications should not be used without pyrazinamide and ethambutol in the initial phase of therapy due to the risk of drug resistance.  
❌ Rifampin, levofloxacin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol:
Incorrect: 4-drug therapy with rifampin, levofloxacin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol is not the standard first-line regimen for treating TB. Levofloxacin is used in cases of resistance or intolerance to first-line agents.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for evaluation of fatigue, polyuria, and unintentional weight gain of 20 lbs (9.1 kg) over the past year. Her past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension treated with low-dose lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 ºF), blood pressure is 162/95 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination is notable for central obesity, with lower abdominal striae and small ecchymoses scattered throughout. Laboratory studies are shown below. The serum cortisol does not suppress with low-dose dexamethasone but with high-dose dexamethasone. Brain MRI shows a large pituitary tumor. Abdominal CT imaging does not show adrenal abnormalities. DXA scan shows a T-score of -2.9. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory study  Result
 Finger stick blood glucose  209 mg/dL 
 Bedtime serum cortisol  12 µg/dL 
 Overnight salivary cortisol  0.63 µg/dL 
 25-hydroxy vitamin D  37 ng/mL (normal range: 30-70 ng/mL)

choices.text: Consult neurosurgery for removal of the pituitary mass
Repeat bone density scan in six months

questions.solution:
This patient has osteoporosis, as indicated by the T-score < -2.5. In this patient’s case, osteoporosis is likely caused by hypercortisolism due to an ACTH-producing pituitary tumor (Cushing disease). Management should first focus on diagnosing and treating the underlying secondary cause of osteoporosis. Therefore this patient should be seen by neurosurgery to evaluate for removal of the pituitary mass.  

Osteoporosis refers to a condition of low bone density, decreased bone mass, and increased risk of fracture. Primary osteoporosis occurs due to bone loss associated with aging, especially in postmenopausal women due to low levels of sex hormones. Secondary osteoporosis occurs due to medical conditions (severe hypercortisolism in this case) or medications (e.g. long-term glucocorticoid use).  

If secondary osteoporosis is diagnosed, the underlying condition should be managed before starting medications for osteoporosis. All patients diagnosed with osteopenia or osteoporosis should be checked for adequate calcium intake and serum vitamin D levels. Resistance training should be recommended to all patients with osteoporosis to improve bone density, muscle mass, and functional status. If patients with secondary causes of osteoporosis continue to have bone loss despite treatment of the underlying etiology, pharmacologic therapy may be warranted.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Consult neurosurgery for removal of the pituitary mass:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prescribe alendronate:
Incorrect: While this patient may end up needing a bisphosphonate, the hypercortisolism from the pituitary tumor is causing secondary osteoporosis and should be addressed first.  
❌ Recommend resistance training:
Incorrect: While resistance training is beneficial for almost all patients and can significantly reduce the risk of osteoporosis and osteoporotic fractures, this patient’s pituitary mass should be addressed as soon as possible.  
❌ Prescribe high-dose ergocalciferol:
Incorrect: While this patient may benefit from vitamin D therapy, her current level is in the normal range and high-dose therapy is not necessary at this time. More importantly, the pituitary tumor is likely causing secondary osteoporosis, which should be addressed first.  
❌ Repeat bone density scan in six months:
Incorrect: This patient has osteoporosis with a likely secondary cause (pituitary mass causing hypercortisolism). There is no reason to wait and repeat imaging. The pituitary mass should be treated now.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic to follow up on recent bone density scan results. The patient’s bone density scan shows a T score of -2.8. Further workup shows no secondary cause of osteoporosis. The patient’s past medical history is significant for hypertension and severe chronic esophagitis with stenosis requiring frequent esophageal dilations. Her current medications include amlodipine, carvedilol, and pantoprazole. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears frail. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has osteoporosis as indicated by a T-score < -2.5. She also has an esophageal disorder which is a contraindication to taking bisphosphonates, which are typically the first-line treatment for osteoporosis. Denosumab, which is a RANK-ligand inhibitor, is an appropriate alternative agent to prescribe for this patient with osteoporosis at high risk for fracture.  

Management of osteoporosis includes making sure patients have adequate calcium intake and checking serum vitamin D levels and supplementing if necessary. Smoking cessation should be recommended for patients who smoke. Resistance training can significantly improve bone density, muscle mass, and functional status and should be recommended for all patients with osteoporosis. Bisphosphonates are antiresorptive agents that are generally the first-line option for treating osteoporosis. However, bisphosphonates are associated with some important side effects, such as pill-related esophagitis, osteonecrosis of the jaw, atypical femoral stress fractures, and renal toxicity. Denosumab (a RANK-ligand inhibitor) is an alternative antiresorptive therapy option for patients who are not candidates for bisphosphonates. In certain cases, including severe osteoporosis, anabolic therapy with teriparatide (a parathyroid hormone analogue) or romosozumab (monoclonal antibody sclerostin inhibitor) may be indicated. In certain postmenopausal women, estrogen-related therapy may be an option if there are contraindications to or intolerance of other agents.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prescribe subcutaneous denosumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Prescribe raloxifene:
Incorrect: Raloxifene is a type of estrogen-related therapy with anti-resorptive properties that can be used for the treatment of osteoporosis in certain post-menopausal women with contraindications or intolerance of other agents.  
❌ Prescribe oral alendronate:
Incorrect: This patient has an esophageal disorder and would not be a good candidate for oral bisphosphonates due to the significant risk for pill-related esophagitis.  
❌ Recommend resistance training:
Incorrect: This patient has osteoporosis and has a contraindication to taking oral bisphosphonates. Another pharmacologic agent should be started in addition to recommending lifestyle changes.  
❌ Recommend increasing dietary calcium intake:
Incorrect: This patient has osteoporosis and has a contraindication to taking oral bisphosphonates. Another pharmacologic agent should be started in addition to recommending lifestyle changes like resistance training and adequate calcium intake.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the clinic because of recurrent kidney stones over the past year. He has passed three stones during this time. His past medical history is notable for major depressive disorder diagnosed 6 months ago. Temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), blood pressure is 136/87 mmHg, pulse is 74/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, he appears alert and oriented. Laboratory results are significant for a serum calcium level of 11.8 mg/dL. Other laboratory results including CBC, creatinine, albumin, and TSH are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to perform next to determine the underlying cause of hypercalcemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent kidney stones and has hypercalcemia. To further evaluate the underlying cause of hypercalcemia, the best next step is to measure parathyroid hormone (PTH) level. Patients with hypercalcemia can present with a wide range of symptoms including polyuria, constipation, kidney stones, bone pain, and neurocognitive dysfunction. The most common causes of hypercalcemia are primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy.      

The initial diagnostic workup for a patient with hypercalcemia begins with confirming the elevated calcium level and, if necessary, adjusting for albumin, as albumin is the primary calcium-binding protein in blood. The next step is to order kidney function tests, as well as a complete blood count to rule out hematologic malignancies. Medications should be reviewed, as certain drugs, such as thiazide diuretics, lithium, vitamin D supplements, and calcium-containing antacids can cause hypercalcemia.    

If there is no obvious cause, then a parathyroid hormone (PTH) level should be checked to distinguish between PTH-mediated and non-PTH-mediated causes of hypercalcemia. Elevated or inappropriately normal PTH indicates primary hyperparathyroidism or familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia, whereas a low PTH suggests a PTH-independent cause such as malignancy or hyperthyroidism. If PTH is not elevated then PTH-related peptide, alkaline phosphatase, and 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D should be checked. TSH and SPEP may be ordered if there is still uncertainty regarding the cause of hypercalcemia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Serum parathyroid hormone (PTH) level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 24-hour urinary calcium excretin:
Incorrect: The best next step is to measure the serum PTH level to assess for underlying primary hyperparathyroidism, since primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy cause most cases of hypercalcemia.   
❌ Serum protein electrophoresis:
Incorrect: Serum electrophoresis is indicated to help diagnose multiple myeloma. It presents with anemia, hypercalcemia, bone pain, and renal insufficiency. This patient should first have serum PTH level checked since primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy cause most cases of hypercalcemia, and he has no other signs or symptoms of multiple myeloma.   
❌ Thyroid ultrasound:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if there was clinical suspicion for hyperthyroidism causing hypercalcemia. This patient's clinical features and the absence of symptoms related to thyroid disease (e.g. weight loss, heat intolerance, or tremors) make this diagnosis less likely, and primary hyperparathyroidism and malignancy cause most cases of hypercalcemia  
❌ Serum 1,25-(OH)2D level:
Incorrect: An elevated serum 1,25-(OH)2D level would suggest granulomatous disease or lymphoma as the etiology of hypercalcemia, and it should be checked initially if any signs or symptoms of granulomatous disease are present. Checking serum 1,25-(OH)2D level is part of the evaluation of patients with hypercalcemia along with PTH-related peptide, alkaline phosphatase, and 1,25 dihydroxy vitamin D, after first checking a PTH level.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with a 3-day history of dysuria, low-grade fever, penile discharge, and right testicular pain. He does not have frequency, urgency, or blood in his urine. He has been sexually active with a new partner without the use of barrier protection. He has a history of cryptorchidism of the right testicle that was surgically corrected with orchiopexy at the age of 1. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, there is no abdominal tenderness. The right testicle appears swollen with associated tenderness to palpation of the posterior and superior aspects. The left testicular exam is normal. The patient feels relief from pain with elevation of the right scrotum. There is minimal white penile discharge. Digital rectal examination is unremarkable. Urinalysis is positive for leukocyte esterase and white blood cells.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This man who presents with dysuria, testicular pain, a positive Prehn sign, and a positive urinalysis likely has epididymitis with urethritis. Epididymitis refers to inflammation of the epididymis that is commonly caused by bacterial infections, and by sexually transmitted infections in sexually active men. C. trachomatis and N. gonorrhoeae are the most frequent causes of epididymitis in sexually active males.    

Patients typically have unilateral testicular pain and tenderness as well as palpable swelling of the epididymis. Symptoms can include testicular pain, swelling, erythema, and dysuria and there may be associated urethritis. Frequently, urethritis is asymptomatic. A key clinical finding that may differentiate epididymitis from other causes of testicular pain, is the Prehn sign, which refers to relief of pain upon elevation of the involved scrotum.   

Option Analysis

✅ Epididymitis with urethritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Testicular torsion:
Incorrect: Testicular torsion is a urological emergency caused by the spermatic cord twisting with subsequent loss of blood flow to the testicle. It presents with sudden, severe testicular pain and swelling. Testicular torsion does not cause dysuria. A key clinical distinction between testicular torsion and epididymitis is that lifting the testicle does not relieve pain (Prehn sign) in testicular torsion.  
❌ Cystitis:
Incorrect: Cystitis refers to inflammation of the bladder, often caused by a urinary tract infection. Symptoms include urinary urgency, frequency, and burning with urination. Hematuria and suprapubic pain can also occur. While the patient presents with dysuria, he also has symptoms and physical exam findings consistent with epididymitis.  
❌ Testicular cancer:
Incorrect: Testicular cancer presents as a unilateral mass or painless swelling found incidentally. Acute pain can be seen but is not common. A solid mass is typically present on examination.  
❌ Acute bacterial prostatitis:
Incorrect: This condition is characterized by inflammation of the prostate gland. While it can present with dysuria and fever, symptoms typically include pelvic or perineal pain, urinary frequency and urgency, chills, and malaise. On digital rectal examination, the prostate may feel tender and boggy. This patient’s physical examination suggests an alternate diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with a 4-day history of dysuria, increased urinary frequency and urgency, and a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying. She does not have fevers, flank pain, vaginal discharge, and itching. She is not sexually active. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, she has suprapubic tenderness, without rebound or guarding. There is no costovertebral angle tenderness. Urinalysis reveals leukocytes and leukocyte esterase, but no nitrites or blood. A clean-catch urine sample is sent for culture. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has cystitis. Cystitis is a urinary tract infection (UTI) of the bladder/lower urinary tract and is most commonly caused by bacterial infections. Typical symptoms of cystitis include dysuria (painful urination), increased frequency of urination, urgency, a sensation of incomplete bladder emptying, and occasionally hematuria. The onset of symptoms tends to be acute, developing over a short period, which aligns with this patient's 4-day history of symptoms. Physical examination may revealsuprapubic tenderness.  

The urinalysis findings further support the diagnosis of cystitis. The presence of pyuria or leukocytes seen on urine microscopy indicates an inflammatory or infectious process within the urinary tract. White blood cell count ≥10 leukocytes/microL is consistent with a urinary tract infection. The presence of nitrites, produced by certain bacteria like E. coli, are often detected in bacterial UTIs, but their absence does not rule out a UTI, especially in the context of symptoms suggestive of cystitis. The presence of leukocyte esterase indicates a urinary tract infection since it is an enzyme released by leukocytes. A urine culture showing bacteriuria (≥105 colony-forming units/mL of a uropathogen) confirms the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Vaginal candidiasis:
Incorrect: Vaginal candidiasis, or yeast infection, is often caused by antibiotic use, which disrupts the normal vaginal flora and allows for Candida overgrowth. Symptoms include itching and burning of the vagina, and a characteristic thick, white "cottage cheese-like" vaginal discharge.   
❌ Gonococcal cervicitis and urethritis:
Incorrect: Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. Cervicitis and urethritis in women are commonly caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. With cervicitis, there is typically a mucopurulent discharge. Urethritis may also be seen concurrently and cause dysuria, however, most women with Neisseria gonorrhoeae are asymptomatic. This diagnosis is unlikely in this patient who is not sexually active.  
❌ Interstitial cystitis:
Incorrect: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition characterized by bladder pain, urgency, frequency, and nocturia. Onset of symptoms in interstitial cystitis tends to be more insidious and chronic, rather than acute, as seen with this patient. The urine is sterile in interstitial cystitis.  
❌ Chlamydial cervicitis and urethritis:
Incorrect: Chlamydia trachomatis is a sexually transmitted bacteria that can cause urethritis, leading to symptoms of dysuria. In women, chlamydial infection can also ascend to involve the cervix, producing a mucopurulent cervical discharge. While this patient does have dysuria, she has no vaginal discharge and is not sexually active.   
✅ Cystitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever for two days. The patient reports fatigue, cough, anorexia, severe headache, sore throat and chills. The patient has also had abdominal cramping and several episodes of hematochezia. The patient is currently being treated for diffuse large B-cell lymphoma and last received chemotherapy three days ago. Temperature is 39.0 °C (102.2 °F), pulse is 108/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 105/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates dry mucous membranes, generalized abdominal tenderness, and a port over the right chest wall. The posterior pharynx appears erythematous. The patient has a stage 2 sacral pressure wound without overlying erythematous changes or exudate. Laboratory studies show an absolute neutrophil count of 300 cells/µL. Which of the following tests or examinations is contraindicated based on this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient who is actively receiving chemotherapy presents with febrile neutropenia (neutropenic fever). This patient has multiple potential sources for a localizing infectious process and should receive a thorough physical examination and workup (e.g., lumbar puncture, chest radiograph, CT imaging of the abdomen). While this patient has evidence of hematochezia, digital rectal examination is contraindicated in patients with febrile neutropenia due to the risk of microtrauma and inadvertent translocation of bacteria into the bloodstream.

Febrile neutropenia is defined as either a single oral temperature of 101 ºF or a temperature of 100.4 ºF lasting an hour or more, in the setting of an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) lower than 1500 cells/µL. Patients on chemotherapy are generally at the highest risk for this condition within the first several days of treatment. Patients should be questioned about any recent port access or minimally invasive procedure (e.g. tooth removal). Physical exam should assess for wounds, indwelling lines or catheters, and any intraoral pathology. Blood cultures should be obtained from two sites including any ports or central lines that are in place. If appropriate, wound culture, urine culture, and lumbar puncture may be performed. Chest radiography should always be performed. CT imaging of the abdomen and pelvis may also be indicated depending on the suspected source of infection.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Digital rectal examination:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wound culture:
Incorrect: Patients with neutropenic fever are at high risk for Gram-negative bacteremia which can occur from wounds. Culturing known wounds does not increase the risk of inducing bacteremia and should always be performed.  
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: This patient has febrile neutropenia and several sources of possible infection. Neutropenia is not an absolute contraindication to performing a lumbar puncture.  
❌ Blood cultures from the port:
Incorrect: Patients with neutropenic fever should have their port accessed and have at least one set blood cultures obtained from it.  
❌ Throat culture:
Incorrect: Throat culture and analysis is not contraindicated in this patient population.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for a follow-up regarding a recent diagnosis of febrile neutropenia in the setting of treatment for acute lymphoblastic leukemia. The patient presented to the emergency department three days ago for evaluation of fever and malaise and was found to be neutropenic. Workup at that time did not demonstrate a source of infection, and blood cultures have demonstrated no growth to date. She was discharged on oral levofloxacin and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid. The patient feels well and has no current symptoms. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 124/65 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient has an absolute neutrophil count obtained today of 2645 cells/µL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Hospitalize the patient again and administer cefepime

questions.solution:
This patient who is actively receiving chemotherapy was hospitalized for febrile neutropenia (neutropenic fever) and discharged on oral antibiotics. Given that this patient has sustained clinical improvement and the current absolute neutrophil count (ANC) is > 500 cells/µL, discontinuation of antibiotic therapy is appropriate.

Patients with confirmed febrile neutropenia should receive initial empiric antibiotics that include an antipseudomonal beta-lactam such as cefepime or piperacillin-tazobactam. If no source is identified and the patient clinically improves, they should be treated for fever of unknown origin and receive continued antibiotic therapy with antipseudomonal agents. Patients should be observed for two days and monitored for adequate response to treatment before discharge or discontinuation of antibiotic therapy. Patients with clinical improvement and a repeat ANC >500 are eligible for discontinuation of antibiotic therapy, while those with a repeat ANC <500 require continued antibiotics. Patients who are not anticipated to have neutropenic fever over 7 days and have no other risk factors for complications of neutropenic fever but continue to have ANC< 500, like the patient in this vignette, can be treated as outpatients with similar empiric coverage (e.g. an antipseudomonal fluoroquinolone and amoxicillin-clavulanic acid). Once the ANC is >500 cells/µL, the antibiotics can be discontinued. Patients showing no clinical improvement and continued neutropenia should be hospitalized (if not already) and have cultures/imaging considered again. Antifungal agents and broader antibacterial agents should also be considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Discontinue antibiotics:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hospitalize the patient again and administer cefepime:
Incorrect: This patient has received appropriate empiric antibiotic coverage, has responded well to treatment, and is no longer neutropenic. Further hospitalization and antibiotics are unnecessary.  
❌ Continue current antibiotics:
Incorrect: Patients with an adequate clinical response to antibiotics (afebrile), no growth on cultures and an absolute neutrophil count >500 do not require continued antibiotic therapy.  
❌ Prescribe azithromycin:
Incorrect: Patients with neutropenic fever and inadequate response to initial antibiotic therapy should receive broadened antimicrobial coverage. This patient has responded adequately and azithromycin is unlikely to provide any significant amount of extra coverage.  
❌ Obtain repeat blood cultures:
Incorrect: This patient has received appropriate antibiotic coverage and has responded well to treatment. Original blood cultures show no growth and no further cultures are necessary.

questions.text: A patient is currently being evaluated for a massive pulmonary embolism in the cardiac intensive care unit. As part of the patient’s evaluation, the jugular vein is assessed to measure jugular venous pressure.  Which of the following anatomic landmarks are best used to identify the internal jugular vein for the performance of this measurement?

choices.text: Between the medial and lateral heads of the sternocleidomastoid
1 cm inferior to the junction of the middle and medial third of the clavicle
Midline between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage

questions.solution:
In the neck, the sigmoid sinus exits the jugular foramen and continues in the neck to form the internal jugular vein (IJV).  The IJV travels within the carotid sheath, lateral to the internal carotid artery, with the vagus nerve sitting between the two vessels.  It joins the subclavian vein to form the brachiocephalic vein at the clavicle level.

Surgical landmarks are used to identify the jugular vein. The anterior triangle of the neck is bound inferiorly by the clavicle by the head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and laterally by the lateral head of the sternocleidomastoid. The internal carotid artery (ICA) is isolated by palpation. Lateral to the ICA lies the internal jugular vein.

JVP ( jugular venous pressure) reflects the right atrial pressure. It is frequently used clinically to assess whether the RAP is elevated (Right-sided congestive heart failure) or low (hypovolemic shock). It can also diagnose pericardial disease, tricuspid valve stenosis, and superior vena cava obstruction.

The right IJV is generally preferred to examine the jugular venous pulse as it is in line with the superior vena cava.  While examining the JVP in a patient, the examiner stands on the patient's right side with the optimal degree of upper body elevation. The degree of upper body elevation refers to the angle at which the venous meniscus is best appreciated. In most cases, it is 45 degrees.

The patient’s head is then turned away, and the head and jaw are tipped slightly upwards. Two rulers are required to assess the JVP. One ruler is placed horizontally from the highest visible pulsation point of the internal jugular vein while the other ruler is crossed at the sternal angle. The RAP is determined by adding the height of the jugular venous column above the sternal angle to the vertical distance from the right atrium to the sternal angle (5cm).  

Option Analysis

✅ Between the medial and lateral heads of the sternocleidomastoid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ 1 cm inferior to the junction of the middle and medial third of the clavicle:
Incorrect: This answer describes the access route and anatomic landmarks for subclavian vein central venous access. The stem above describes central venous access obtained through the internal jugular vein.  
❌ Second intercostal space, midclavicular line:
Incorrect: This anatomic site references the site for thoracic needle decompression, not central venous access. A needle and catheter should be placed on the superior aspect of the rib to avoid damage to intercostal vasculature and nerve.  
❌ Fourth intercostal space midaxillary line:
Incorrect: This stem describes one of the anatomic sites for tube thoracostomy (chest tube placement), not central venous access.  
❌ Midline between the thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage:
Incorrect: These anatomic landmarks are used for palpation of the cricothyroid membrane--the site of access for emergent cricothyrotomy and tracheostomy placement.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. The patient presented to her dialysis appointment today and was noted to be hypotensive, and she was subsequently referred to the emergency department. The patient's past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and end-stage renal disease. The patient appears short of breath. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 95/71 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates jugular venous distension. The patient's chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following additional examination findings is most likely to be present?
 

Reproduced from: openi

choices.text: Diminished breath sounds over the lung bases

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of end-stage renal disease presents with hypotension, jugular venous distension, and a “water bottle sign” on chest radiography, suggestive of a moderate pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. A physical exam finding of muffled heart sounds would be consistent with the diagnosis of pericardial effusion and tamponade. Patients like this one who are on dialysis are susceptible to developing uremic pericardial effusions with the potential for tamponade.

Patients with cardiac tamponade often present with chest discomfort, shortness of breath, and generalized malaise and weakness. Clinical manifestations associated with the diagnosis include hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension (Becks triad). Patients may also develop Kussmaul sign, where jugular venous pressure increases with inspiration. Patients may also have evidence of pulsus paradoxus, where inspiration induces a drop in systolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg or greater.  

Option Analysis

✅ Muffled heart sounds:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Absent unilateral breath sounds:
Incorrect: Absent unilateral breath sounds would suggest a pneumothorax. This patient has a chest x-ray suggestive showing cardiomegaly and a “water bottle sign” suggestive of a moderate pericardial effusion in this case.  
❌ Unilateral lower extremity swelling:
Incorrect: Unilateral lower extremity swelling would suggest a deep vein thrombosis and a possible pulmonary embolism as the etiology of this patient's presentation. This patient's presentation is more consistent with cardiac tamponade secondary to a moderate pericardial effusion.  
❌ Diminished breath sounds over the lung bases:
Incorrect: Diminished breath sounds over the lung bases would suggest pleural effusions. This patient's x-ray does not demonstrate evidence of pleural effusions.  
❌ Regurgitant murmur:
Incorrect: A regurgitant murmur could suggest a diagnosis of aortic dissection. This patient does not have evidence of a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray and the finding of a moderate pericardial effusion is more consistent with a diagnosis of pericardial tamponade.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath. The patient recently had a pacemaker placed two days ago for complete heart block. The patient's past medical history includes coronary artery disease, diabetes, hypertension, and rheumatoid arthritis. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 85/71 mmHg, pulse is 109/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals jugular venous distention and muffled heart sounds. A bedside ultrasound demonstrates a large pericardial effusion with a collapse of the right atrium and right ventricle. The patient is started on intravenous fluids and a pericardiocentesis is performed, which reveals gross blood. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a history of a recent pacemaker placement and findings consistent with cardiac tamponade. A pericardiocentesis reveals gross blood, suggestive of a hemorrhagic pericardial effusion from iatrogenic trauma requiring surgical consultation.

Hemorrhagic pericardial effusions can be caused by malignancy, tuberculosis, and percutaneous interventional procedures, as is likely in this case. When blood is surrounding the heart in the pericardial space it is known as hemopericardium. Patients with evidence of hemopericardium require surgical consultation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Surgical consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Emergent hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Emergent hemodialysis is indicated for patients with uremic pericarditis, in which the fluid would be pericardial fluid straw-colored, clear, and inflammatory. This patient has evidence of a hemorrhagic effusion on pericardiocentesis, requiring surgical consultation.  
❌ Empiric antibiotics:
Incorrect: Empiric antibiotics are indicated for pericardial fluid that appears cloudy, and purulent, or for patients with evidence of an associated infectious process/symptoms. This patient has evidence of a hemorrhagic effusion, requiring surgical consultation.  
❌ Cytology analysis:
Incorrect: Cytology analysis is indicated for pericardial effusions in patients with a history suggestive of an underlying malignancy. Malignancy can be caused when pericardial fluid is straw-colored, clear, or inflammatory. Cytology would demonstrate the presence of malignant cells.  
❌ Administration of heparin:
Incorrect: Heparin is not indicated in the management of cardiac tamponade, and in this patient with hemopericardium, it would likely worsen active bleeding.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician for routine follow-up in the springtime. The patient reports frequent sneezing, rhinorrhea and watery eyes since she started training for an upcoming marathon. Past medical history is also notable for well-controlled asthma. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler on an as-needed basis. The patient does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F ), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 120/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows a prominent nasal crease. The nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray. There is a copious thin and watery nasal mucus. The physician starts the patient on oral loratadine. The mechanism of this medication is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sneezing, rhinorrhea and watery eyes consistent with allergic rhinitis.  Allergic rhinitis is an example of a Type I, or IgE mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Histamine is a small molecule stored in mast cells and basophils that mediates allergic, inflammatory and other physiologic processes throughout the body by binding to four different receptors (H1, H2, H3, H4).  Histamine plays an important role in Type I hypersensitivity reactions by binding to H1 receptors, causing local inflammation and vasodilation.

In a Type 1 allergic reaction, an allergen, such as pollen, enters the body and activates B cells. Activated B-cells produce IgE antibodies that get released into the bloodstream and bind to mast cells. The mast cells are now “primed,” meaning that if pollen enters the body again in the future, the mast cells degranulate and release their histamine into the local tissue.

Antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine and loratadine) reduce itching, sneezing, and rhinorrhea by blocking H1 receptors on endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, sensory nerve endings, and in the brain.
   

Option Analysis

✅ Antagonism of H1 receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Antagonism of H2 receptors:
Incorrect: H2 antagonists target the H2 receptors found in gastric parietal cells.  They are effective in the treatment of gastroesophageal reflux and peptic ulcers by blocking gastric acid secretion, but are not useful in the treatment of allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Stimulation of somatostatin receptors:
Incorrect: Somatostatin receptors agonists (e.g. octreotide) inhibit bioactive amine release and are used to treat diarrhea in patients with carcinoid syndrome and VIPoma.  
❌ Antagonism of nicotinic receptors:
Incorrect: Nicotinic receptor antagonists (e.g. rocuronium) are used to induce paralysis in preparation for surgery and endotracheal intubation. They are not effective in allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Antagonism of serotonin 5-HT3 receptors:
Incorrect: Serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonists (e.g. ondansetron) are used primarily to treat nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to the office because of a five-day history of high fevers. The fevers occur intermittently, and he has not noticed a pattern as to when they occur. The fevers are accompanied by muscle aches, chills, and night sweats. He lives in Massachusetts and recently returned from a global surgery trip to Africa. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, which is well controlled with metformin. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Peripheral blood smear reveals trophozoites and schizonts. After further evaluation, the patient is started on high-dose quinine. This medication is associated with which of the following side effects?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irregular pattern of fevers, chills, and myalgias after returning from a malaria-endemic area. In addition, a blood smear reveals trophozoites and schizonts. These findings are concerning for Plasmodium falciparum infection. The patient is started on high-dose quinine therapy and is at increased risk of developing cinchonism, which constellates gastrointestinal distress, headache, vertigo, blurred vision, and tinnitus symptoms.

Apart from quinine, other quinoline-based antimalarial medications include quinidine and chloroquine. These medications can all cause gastrointestinal distress and headaches. Quinidine can also cause cinchonism as well as arrhythmias and long QT syndrome. As a result, the medication should be avoided in individuals with cardiac problems. Chloroquine can cause pruritus and, if used over long periods, can cause retinopathy, which is reversible if the medication is stopped.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Nocturnal leg cramps:
Incorrect: Quinine is moderately effective in decreasing the frequency and intensity of muscle cramps. As a result, nocturnal leg cramps are not a side effect of quinine therapy.  
❌ Diabetic retinopathy:
Incorrect: Quinine is not known to cause diabetic retinopathy.  
✅ Cinchonism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Idiopathic intracranial hypertension:
Incorrect: Tetracycline, vitamin A derivatives, and oral contraceptives, but not quinine, are associated with an increased risk of developing idiopathic intracranial hypertension.  
❌ Psychosis and seizure:
Incorrect: Oral mefloquine is generally well tolerated. However, the United States FDA has added a “black box” warning to mefloquine, noting the drug’s potential to cause severe, possibly permanent, neurological and psychiatric adverse effects. However, quinine therapy has not been associated with these side effects.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise, and fatigue for the past seven days. The patient returned from his cousin’s wedding in Africa three weeks ago. The patient was prescribed chemoprophylaxis but did not take it regularly. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination reveals pale conjunctiva and an enlarged spleen. Peripheral blood smear shows trophozoites and schizonts. Appropriate treatment is started, and the patient is discharged. He returns to the emergency department 2-days later following a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. His partner, accompanying him, recalls that the patient showed signs of improvement until the seizure. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s complication?
questions.solution:
This patient was started on an antimalarial regimen that likely included mefloquine, often used with artesunate to treat chloroquine-resistant malaria.

Common adverse effects of mefloquine include gastrointestinal distress, skin rash, headache, and dizziness. Mefloquine can cause cardiac conduction defects and neuropsychiatric complications (e.g., seizures, psychosis, depression).  

Option Analysis

❌ Primaquine:
Incorrect: Primaquine can cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate-dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency and is contraindicated in pregnancy. However, it is not associated with neurological complications such as seizures.  
❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine can cause pruritus and its long term use can cause retinopathy. It is not associated with neurological complications such as seizures.  
❌ Quinine:
Incorrect: Quinine has been associated with cinchonism, a constellation of gastrointestinal distress, headache, vertigo, blurred vision, and tinnitus. In addition, the medication is associated with an increased risk of arrhythmias and long QT syndrome.  
✅ Mefloquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Doxycycline:
Incorrect: Doxycycline is a tetracycline associated with esophageal ulceration, photosensitivity, and gastrointestinal discomfort. It is not associated with an increased risk of seizures.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise and fatigue for the past 7 days. The patient recently returned from a safari in Africa. She received chemoprophylaxis with mefloquine during the trip and discontinued it upon returning. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies and fibromyalgia. Family history is significant for hypertension in the patient’s father. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva. Laboratory evaluation shows mild anemia and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral blood smear results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, chills, and myalgias after recent travel to a malaria-endemic region and incomplete chemoprophylaxis. A peripheral blood smear reveals banana-shaped gametocytes. In combination, these findings are concerning for Plasmodium falciparum malaria.

The first-line treatment options for chloroquine-resistant malaria within endemic areas include artemisinins (e.g., artemisinin, artesunate, dihydroartemisinin) or atovaquone and proguanil, which are well tolerated and have excellent cure rates. Artemisinins should be administered with a second agent (e.g., artemether-lumefantrine, artesunate-amodiaquine, artesunate-mefloquine) with a longer half-life to prevent the development of artemisinin resistance and provide an extended duration of drug level to clear parasitemia.

Chloroquine is the treatment of choice for malaria acquired in chloroquine-sensitive areas (e.g., Haiti, the Dominican Republic, most regions of the Middle East, and Central America west of the Panama Canal).  

Option Analysis

❌ Atovaquone and azithromycin:
Incorrect: Atovaquone and azithromycin are the treatment of choice for babesiosis. The condition is most common in the northeastern United States, and patients present with hemolytic anemia and fever. A peripheral blood smear will reveal merozoites in the shape of a “Maltese cross”. In contrast, this patient’s history and laboratory findings suggest infection by Plasmodium falciparum.  
✅ Atovaquone and proguanil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine:
Incorrect: Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine is the treatment of choice for toxoplasmosis. The infection is asymptomatic in immunocompetent patients but can rarely present with mononucleosis-like symptoms. In contrast, this patient’s history and laboratory findings suggest infection by Plasmodium falciparum.  
❌ Metronidazole and paromomycin:
Incorrect: Metronidazole effectively treats Entamoeba histolytica, which can cause dysentery and extraintestinal abscesses in the liver, lung, and brain. Paromomycin can be administered to eliminate residual cysts in the gastrointestinal lumen.  
❌ Chloroquine and primaquine:
Incorrect: Most Plasmodium falciparum strains in Africa are resistant to chloroquine. Therefore, alternate agents are required to treat this patient’s symptoms.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of fever, myalgias, and chills for the past two days. The patient does not have cough, dysuria, diarrhea, convulsions, or recent sick contacts. However, she returned from an overseas trip to India around 2-months ago. She had similar symptoms in Nigeria during her first month there, which resolved completely after appropriate treatment. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus, jaundice, and hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory results show mild anemia and hyperbilirubinemia. Peripheral blood smear results are shown below. Addition of which of the following to the patient’s prophylaxis regimen would have helped prevent the development of her current symptoms?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient recently returned from a trip to a malaria-endemic region and most likely acquired a Plasmodium infection. The recurrence of symptoms 2-months later and Schuffner granules' presence in erythrocytes suggest recurrent Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale parasitemia.

Unlike Plasmodium falciparum, P. vivax and P. ovale undergo a dormant hepatic phase (hypnozoite stage) that may cause recurrence weeks to months after the initial infection. Patients infected with these strains should be treated with antimalarial agents that target the erythrocytic stage (e.g. chloroquine) and hepatic dormant stage (e.g. primaquine), also termed the non-erythrocytic stage, to ensure clearance.  

Option Analysis

❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine has activity against the blood stages of Plasmodium ovale, Plasmodium malariae, and susceptible strains of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium falciparum. It has no activity against dormant pathogens.  
❌ Arthemether:
Incorrect: Arthemether is an artemisinin derivative that acts rapidly to kill the blood stages of all Plasmodium species. However, it has no activity against parasites in the dormant stage of infection.  
✅ Primaquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ivermectin:
Incorrect: Ivermectin is an anthelmintic drug approved for oral treatment of onchocerciasis and strongyloidiasis. It is not effective in the treatment of malaria.  
❌ Mefloquine:
Incorrect: Mefloquine is a highly effective blood schizonticide that is thought to work by inhibiting protein synthesis in Plasmodium species. It has no activity against dormant pathogens.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate due to altered mental status. According to the roommate, the patient appeared confused and mumbled about how “spies” were trying to sabotage her homework assignment. Past medical history is notable for depression for which she takes fluoxetine. Earlier in the day, the patient visited her university health clinic due to cold symptoms and was prescribed an antitussive. Temperature is 40.2°C (104.4°F), blood pressure is 157/96 mmHg, and pulse is 126/min. The patient is oriented to self but not place or time. The skin appears flushed and is warm to touch. 4+ reflexes are elicited in the upper and lower extremities. What is the primary mechanism of action of the antitussive responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, autonomic instability, and hyperreflexia. She has been taking fluoxetine and was started on a new antitussive. Together, these findings are concerning for serotonin syndrome. The new medication was most likely dextromethorphan, which works primarily by antagonizing NMDA receptors but also exerts serotonergic effects.     

Dextromethorphan is an antitussive that can be used to relieve cough caused by minor viral upper respiratory tract infections or inhaled irritants. It acts primarily by antagonizing NMDA glutamate receptors. This medication is a codeine-analog and has mild opioid effects when used in excess. As a result, the medication carries mild abuse potential. Moreover, dextromethorphan can inhibit serotonin reuptake and can precipitate serotonin syndrome, especially when taken in combination with selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs).    

Side effects, particularly with overdose, include hallucinations, confusion, euphoria, nausea, vomiting, and nystagmus. In severe cases, patients may experience seizures, coma, and respiratory depression.     

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulation of muscarinic receptors:
Incorrect: Guaifenesin stimulates muscarinic receptors, which in turn, triggers submucosal glands to produce well-hydrated secretions. Guaifenesin is an expectorant, not an antitussive. Furthermore, guaifenesin would not precipitate serotonin syndrome.  
✅ Blockade of NMDA receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Disruption of disulfide bonds:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is a mucolytic that thins mucus by disrupting disulfide bonds. N-acetylcysteine is neither an antitussive nor would it precipitate serotonin syndrome when used in combination with fluoxetine.  
❌ Antagonization of H1 receptors:
Incorrect: Antihistamines (e.g. diphenhydramine, loratadine, cetirizine) prevent respiratory smooth muscle constriction and mucus production. These medications can be used to treat symptoms of nasal congestion caused by allergies or the common cold. Antihistamines would not trigger serotonin syndrome when used in combination with fluoxetine.  
❌ Inhibition of monoamine oxidase activity:
Incorrect: Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (e.g. phenelzine, tranylcypromine) are antidepressants that increase serotonin levels and can precipitate serotonin syndrome. However, this patient’s symptoms developed after starting a new antitussive, not a new antidepressant.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to an employee health fair at the hospital where she works as a nurse. The patient is feeling well and does not have any symptoms. Her past medical history is notable for asthma, for which she intermittently uses an albuterol inhaler. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), blood pressure is 123/78 mmHg, and pulse is 65/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. A purified protein derivative injection is performed, and after two days, a wheal measuring 12 mm in diameter is observed at the injection site. The patient is started on a medication that can cause side effects, including elevations in liver enzymes, reduced sensation in the extremities, and the development of a malar rash. Which of the following best describes this medication’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Generation of free radicals that damage DNA

questions.solution:
This asymptomatic patient works in a healthcare setting and has a positive tuberculin skin test. She likely has latent tuberculosis and was initiated on isoniazid, which can cause hepatotoxicity, peripheral neuropathy, and drug-induced lupus.  

Isoniazid can be used as monotherapy for prophylaxis or treatment of latent tuberculosis. It can be used in combination with other medications to treat active tuberculosis. Isoniazid is converted by the mycobacterial enzyme catalase-peroxidase into its active metabolite iproniazid, inhibiting mycolic acid synthesis. The medication also inhibits mycobacterial peroxidase and prevents the bacteria from metabolizing hydrogen peroxide, which accumulates intracellularly, causing damage to the cell. Mycobacteria can develop resistance if mutations form in the catalase-peroxidase gene.    

Side effects of isoniazid include rash, fever, and drug-induced lupus. It can also cause vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) deficiency, which leads to sideroblastic anemia. Pyridoxine deficiency also leads to neurological symptoms, including dizziness, ataxia, or encephalopathy, but the most common is peripheral neuropathy. Fortunately, these side effects can be prevented with the concurrent administration of pyridoxine. Isoniazid can also cause hepatotoxicity and inhibit cytochrome P450. Finally, in overdose cases, the drug can cause seizures, anion gap metabolic acidosis, and coma.  



Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of arabinogalactan synthesis:
Incorrect: Ethambutol inhibits the enzyme arabinosyltransferase, thereby preventing the synthesis of arabinogalactan–a component of the mycobacterial cell wall. Ethambutol can cause optic neuritis and hyperuricemia. However, it would not account for the constellation of side effects described in the question stem.  
❌ Inhibition of DNA-dependent RNA polymerase:
Incorrect: Rifampin is an antituberculosis drug that works by inhibiting mycobacterial RNA polymerase. Although this drug can cause hepatitis and elevated liver enzymes, it would not typically cause peripheral neuropathy or drug-induced lupus.  
❌ Generation of free radicals that damage DNA:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is an antibiotic that generates free radicals, which can damage bacterial and protozoal DNA. This medication can treat protozoal (e.g., Entamoeba histolytica, Giardia lamblia) and anaerobic bacterial infections. However, metronidazole is not used to treat tuberculosis and would not cause drug-induced lupus or peripheral neuropathy.  
❌ Blockade of bacterial ribosomal 30S subunit:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides, such as streptomycin, act on the 30S subunit of mycobacterial ribosomes, thereby inhibiting protein synthesis. Side effects of these medications include rash, fever, ototoxicity, and ataxia. Aminoglycosides are not used as monotherapy for the treatment of tuberculosis. Furthermore, they would not account for the constellation of side effects described in the question stem.  
✅ Inhibition of mycolic acid synthesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for a routine visit. The patient is feeling well and has no symptoms. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. He works as a consultant and frequently travels overseas to meet with clients in China and India. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 157/86 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. A purified protein derivative injection is performed. After two days, a wheal measuring 16 mm in diameter is present at the injection site. An interferon-gamma test is performed and returns positive. The patient is initiated on a medication that inhibits the bacterial synthesis of mycolic acid. Which of the following additional medications should be administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has traveled to tuberculosis-endemic regions and has a positive tuberculin skin test and interferon-gamma assay but remains asymptomatic. He likely has latent tuberculosis and was appropriately initiated on isoniazid therapy. Patients on isoniazid should also receive vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) supplementation.  

Isoniazid can be used alone to treat latent tuberculosis or in combination with other medications to treat active tuberculosis. The medication inhibits mycolic acid synthesis, an essential component of the mycobacterial cell wall. It also inhibits mycobacterial peroxidase, which leads to hydrogen peroxide accumulation within mycobacteria inducing cellular damage.    

Isoniazid use may lead to pyridoxine deficiency, manifest with sideroblastic anemia, encephalopathy, ataxia, dizziness, and peripheral neuropathy. Fortunately, these side effects can be prevented with pyridoxine supplementation. As a result, patients taking isoniazid should receive daily pyridoxine.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Ethambutol:
Incorrect: Ethambutol is a medication used to treat active tuberculosis. Ethambutol works by inhibiting arabinogalactan synthesis, as opposed to mycolic acid synthesis. In contrast, this patient has evidence of latent tuberculosis since he remains asymptomatic despite having a positive purified protein derivative (PPD) test and interferon-gamma assay.  
❌ Vitamin B1:
