choices.text: Administer 0.9% normal saline boluses and insulin infusion
Administer half-isotonic saline boluses and insulin infusion

questions.solution:
This patient with poorly-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with altered mental status with a normal blood pH, blood glucose >600 mg/dL, elevated serum osmolality, and minimal-to-no ketonuria meets criteria for hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. This patient is also hypotensive, and initial management should include administration of intravenous 0.9% normal saline boluses followed by insulin infusion.

Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) is a life-threatening complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus that results in relative insulin deficiency, hyperglycemia, and elevated serum osmolality. It usually occurs in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus where there is a triggering event, such as illness or infection, as seen in this case. The diagnosis of HHS requires laboratory studies that demonstrate an elevated blood glucose and serum osmolality as well as the absence of metabolic acidosis and ketonuria.

The acute management of suspected HHS begins with an ABCDE assessment to determine if the patient is unstable or stable. Patients with HHS can present with hemodynamic instability due to large, multi-liter volume deficits secondary to osmotic diuresis. IV access should be obtained and patients should have 1-liter boluses of isotonic IV fluid and then a continuous infusion. Airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized. Patients should have continuous vital sign monitoring and be provided with supplemental oxygen, if needed. Patients should have lab work obtained to confirm the diagnosis, including an ABG/VBG, CMP, urinalysis, and serum osmolality; once the diagnosis is made, intravenous insulin should be started.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer 0.9% normal saline boluses and insulin infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer half-isotonic saline boluses and insulin infusion:
Incorrect: Volume resuscitation is a critical aspect of treating patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state and hypotension. Initially patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) and hypovolemic shock should be given isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline). Typically after a few hours of this, the corrected sodium concentration should be used to determine which type of saline to continue.  
❌ Administer 0.9% normal saline infusion:
Incorrect: While volume resuscitation is a critical aspect of treating hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state, this patient should also receive treatment with intravenous insulin once the diagnosis of hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) is confirmed with laboratory studies.  
❌ Administer fomepizole:
Incorrect: Fomepizole is indicated for the treatment of toxic alcohol ingestions, such as methanol. While this patient has an elevated serum osmolality, he does not have evidence of metabolic acidosis, which is seen with toxic alcohol ingestions.  
❌ Administer naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is indicated in the management of acute opioid overdose. Opioid overdose is characterized by miosis, respiratory depression, and apnea—none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man comes to the office for routine follow-up. He was diagnosed with dyslipidemia 6 months ago on a fasting lipid panel. He has no active complaints at this visit. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes daily, drinks 2-3 beers on weekends and does not use recreational drugs. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg. His BMI is 32.5 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A repeat fasting lipid panel was obtained during today’s visit. Comparison of the results is shown below. The physician counseled him about dietary modifications and decided to add another lipid-lowering drug to this patient’s medication regimen which inhibits bile acid reabsorption in the intestine. Which of the following is the most likely medication this patient was started on?  

Laboratory value
6 months ago
Today
Total cholesterol
370 mg/dL
301 mg/dL
Low-density lipoprotein (LDL)  
250 mg/dL
175 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)  
30 mg/dL
33 mg/dL
Triglycerides (TGs)  
90 mg/dL
89 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has hypercholesterolemia which is not significantly improving with mono-therapy with statins (atorvastatin). The new drug added to his regime is a bile acid resin, common examples of which include cholestyramine, colestipol and colesevelam.

Bile acid resins are large, positively-charged molecules that bind to the negatively-charged bile acid in the intestine, inhibiting reabsorption at the intestinal brush border. The liver compensates for the decreased bile acids by increasing the production of bile salts via its up-regulation of LDL receptor and an increase in the synthesis of hydroxymethylglutaryl (HMG) CoA reductase (which converts HMG CoA to mevalonate, a cholesterol precursor). Bile acid resins are not as effective as statins, which increase the LDL receptors and inhibit HMG-CoA, and that is why they are usually used in combination with statins. The LDL receptors also very slightly increase the uptake of VLDL. A minor increase in HDL levels is also observed. Its combination with a non-statin lipid-lowering agent (e.g., niacin, fibrates) may be useful in patients who are statin-intolerant and require intensive lipid-lowering therapy. Common adverse effects associated with bile acid resins include gastrointestinal upset (nausea, bloating and cramping) and impaired absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E and K) and drugs (e.g., digoxin, warfarin).  

Option Analysis

❌ Niacin:
Incorrect:  Niacin, a lipid lowering drug, acts to prevent lipolysis by inhibiting hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue. Its overall effect is a major increase in HDL and a decrease in LDL. It, however, does not affect intestinal absorption of bile acids.  
✅ Cholestyramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fenofibrate:
Incorrect: This drug is a fibrate that activates PPAR-α, causing the up-regulation of lipoprotein lipase levels to increase the clearance of serum triglycerides. This class of drugs also decreases very-low-density lipoproteins (VLDL) and induces HDL synthesis. It has no effect on bile acid reabsorption.  
❌ Ezetimibe:
Incorrect: Ezetimibe inhibits cholesterol (not bile acid) absorption at the intestinal brush border, reducing liver cholesterol stores and decreasing biliary bile content.  
❌ Alirocumab:
Incorrect: Alirocumab is a PCSK9 inhibitor that acts by inhibiting the degradation of LDL-R, facilitating the removal of LDL from the bloodstream. No effect on intestinal bile acid absorption is observed with the use of this drug.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is found to have a deep vein thrombosis following an uncomplicated total left hip arthroplasty. The patient and physician decide to pursue anticoagulation with a medication with a low therapeutic index and requires frequent laboratory monitoring to ensure that the medication is in the therapeutic window. Which of the following medications is most likely being administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
Multiple medications are known for their low therapeutic index (TI), including warfarin, an anticoagulant often used to treat acute pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis. This medication requires frequent international normalized ratio (INR) checks to ensure therapeutic anticoagulation.  

The TI is a quantitative measurement of the relative safety of a drug and is calculated by taking the median toxic dose (TD50) divided by the median effective dose (ED50). It represents the range of drug concentrations that can safely and effectively treat a particular disease. Medications with a lower TI are less favorable than those with a higher TI since a small dosage can potentially produce toxic effects. Mathematically, the closer the ratio is to 1, the higher the danger of the toxicity.  

Commonly used medications known to have a lower TI include warfarin, lithium, theophylline, digoxin, as well as certain antiepileptics. These medications often require frequent monitoring and dosage adjustment due to their pharmacological profile and potential for adverse effects.

Option Analysis

✅ Warfarin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is an antiplatelet medication that does not require frequent lab monitoring. Moreover, this medication is not a first-line treatment for acute deep vein thrombosis.  
❌ Enoxaparin sodium:
Incorrect: Enoxaparin sodium is a form of heparin that does not require frequent laboratory monitoring (although it is routinely used in treating deep vein thrombosis). It is typically provided via subcutaneous injection over the lower abdomen.   
❌ Apixaban :
Incorrect: Apixaban is a direct factor Xa inhibitor that does not require frequent laboratory monitoring. However, it can be used in the treatment of deep vein thrombosis.  
❌ Clopidogrel:
Incorrect: Clopidogrel is another antiplatelet medication frequently used with aspirin to treat acute coronary syndrome or recurrent strokes. Clopidogrel does not require frequent laboratory monitoring.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for a routine physical. He reports worsening fatigue for the last five weeks as well as a worsening cough for three months. Past medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypercholesterolemia for which he takes atorvastatin. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. He does drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. The patient has lost 15 pounds since his last visit six months ago. He has not had blood in the stool. Temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 91/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, blood pressure is 126/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, he appears pale with mild conjunctival pallor. Pulmonary auscultation reveals expiratory wheezes bilaterally. Cardiac exam shows tachycardia but is otherwise unremarkable. A complete blood count (CBC) is obtained with results shown below. Which of the following additional test results would be most consistent with the likely diagnosis?  

Laboratory value
Result
Hemoglobin
9.8 g/dL
Hematocrit
29.4%
Mean corpuscular volume
75 fL
Reticulocyte count
0.7%
Ferritin
450 µg/L

choices.text: Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and low serum iron concentration
Decreased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and low serum iron concentration
Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and basophilic stippling of red blood cells
Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and high serum iron concentration
Normal total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and high serum iron concentration

questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, a 15-lb unintentional weight loss, new cough, as well as COPD, and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He likely has anemia of chronic disease secondary to lung cancer.

Anemia of chronic disease (also known as anemia of inflammation) (ACD/AI) is a microcytic or normocytic anemia that can be seen in disease states that cause chronic inflammation. ACD/AI occurs in the setting of chronic conditions, such as malignancy, infection, or autoimmune diseases. Chronic inflammation dysregulates iron homeostasis, primarily by increasing hepcidin and other cytokines, to prevent iron release. This sequestration results in low serum iron, high ferritin (because iron stores are full and because of chronic inflammation), low transferrin saturation (TSAT), and low total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) (because iron is unavailable).

Results from iron studies (i.e. serum iron, ferritin, transferrin saturation [TSAT], and total iron-binding capacity [TIBC]) can help to narrow down the etiology of microcytic anemia as indicated in the table below.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and low serum iron concentration:
Incorrect: These findings are consistent with iron deficiency anemia. This patient’s history is highly suggestive of a pulmonary malignancy, which can be associated with anemia of chronic disease, and would present with a decreased TIBC.  
✅ Decreased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and low serum iron concentration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and basophilic stippling of red blood cells:
Incorrect: Microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling is associated with lead poisoning and sideroblastic anemia. However, anemia of chronic disease is more likely in this patient with unintentional weight loss, cough, COPD, and a significant smoking history.  
❌ Elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and high serum iron concentration:
Incorrect: Elevated TIBC is associated with iron deficiency or lead poisoning. Decreased TIBC is seen in anemia of chronic disease.  
❌ Normal total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) and high serum iron concentration:
Incorrect: These results are consistent with sideroblastic anemia, which is most commonly due to chronic alcohol use or heavy metal poisoning. This patient does not have any apparent exposures, and his presentation is more consistent with anemia of chronic disease secondary to malignancy.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic for his routine visit. In the past six months, he has noticed fatigue, diffuse itchiness, and decreased urine production. He has a 20-year history of diabetes and has not seen a doctor since he lost insurance coverage six years ago. He has not had blood in the stool. Temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, and blood pressure is 175/95 mmHg. On physical examination, he has conjunctival pallor and 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the knees. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Results of laboratory testing are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step for determining the cause of anemia in this patient?  

Laboratory value
Result
Hemoglobin
9.4 g/dL
Hematocrit
28%
Mean corpuscular volume
85 fL
Reticulocyte count
0.4%
Sodium
134 mEq/L
Potassium
5.3 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen
77 mg/dL
Creatinine
6.3 mg/dL (previously 1.7 mg/dL)

choices.text: Check serum B12 and folate levels

questions.solution:
Anemia of Chronic Kidney Disease

This patient with long-standing diabetes presents with fatigue, pruritus, edema, and hypertension. Labs show normocytic anemia, uremia, and elevated creatinine. Together, these findings suggest chronic kidney disease (CKD) secondary to diabetes. Chronic kidney disease can lead to decreased production of erythropoietin and a normocytic anemia. The first step for determining the cause of anemia in this patient is to calculate the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR).

Anemia of CKD is a common comorbidity that results from reduced production of erythropoietin by the kidneys as well as a shortened red blood cell lifespan. This usually presents as a normocytic, normochromic anemia. CKD can be diagnosed as the primary etiology of anemia only after excluding other causes. Evaluation includes a complete blood count with differential, iron studies, and testing for the presence of blood in stool. When mean corpuscular volume is increased, B12 and folate levels should also be checked. Therapy with erythropoietin-stimulating agents should only be initiated following a negative workup of non-renal causes and confirmation of CKD.  

Option Analysis

✅ Calculate estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Schedule bone marrow aspiration:
Incorrect: Examination of the bone marrow can identify etiologies directly affecting hematopoiesis, such as aplasia or myelodysplastic syndrome. This patient’s presentation is consistent with anemia of chronic kidney disease, which impacts the stimulation of hematopoiesis.  
❌ Check blood lead level:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning results in microcytic anemia, not normocytic anemia.  
❌ Check serum B12 and folate levels:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 and folate deficiencies both result in macrocytic anemia. This patient has normocytic anemia.  
❌ Assess peripheral smear:
Incorrect: Looking at red blood cell morphology via peripheral smear can be helpful in differentiating causes of microcytosis and macrocytosis. This patient has normocytic anemia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of fever and severe pain and swelling in her left thigh for 5 days. She has a history of less severe recurrent painful episodes in her long bones since childhood, and she had frequent middle ear infections as a child. She was adopted; she knows her biological mother was a Black woman of Nigerian descent who had a history of anemia, but she is unsure of the details. She is not sexually active. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 21/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals pallor and scleral icterus. The left thigh is swollen, erythematous, warm, and tender to palpation. Blood culture reveals gram-negative rods. MRI of the thigh shows a focal area of increased signal intensity with surrounding edema. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of recurrent pain crises, frequent ear infections (likely from Strep. pneumoniae, an encapsulated bacteria), and a family history of chronic anemia presents with fever and localized left thigh pain, swelling, warmth, and erythema, along with MRI findings of increased signal intensity surrounded by edema. She most likely has sickle cell disease (SCD) with osteomyelitis. Given the gram negative rods seen on bacterial cultures, the most likely diagnosis is acute osteomyelitis caused by Salmonella spp. Salmonella is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD.  

Patients with SCD can have recurrent acute painful episodes of bone pain caused by vaso-occlusion, and acute chest pain in SCD can be a sign of acute chest syndrome. Recurrent jaundice, anemia, and the absence of a palpable spleen on physical examination suggest chronic hemolysis and functional asplenia.   

Osteomyelitis is a common complication in patients with SCD. When sickled red blood cells obstruct blood vessels it can lead to local ischemia and bone infarction. Infarcted necrotic bone becomes vulnerable to bacterial infection, and functional asplenia increases the risk of infections. Most cases of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD are caused by gram-negative organisms, especially Salmonella spp. and Escherichia coli.  

Option Analysis

✅ Salmonella spp.:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Pseudomonas aeruginosa:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and presentation are characteristic of sickle cell disease (SCD) with osteomyelitis. P. aeruginosa is a known cause of osteomyelitis, especially in patients with puncture wounds or a history of intravenous drug use; however, Salmonella spp. is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD.
❌ Neisseria gonorrhea:
Incorrect: Osteomyelitis due to N. gonorrhea is more common in sexually active adults. In addition, this patient’s history and presentation is characteristic of sickle cell disease (SCD), which is more commonly associated with osteomyelitis caused by Salmonella spp.  
❌ Staphylococcus aureus:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and presentation are characteristic of sickle cell disease (SCD) with osteomyelitis. While Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in the general population, Salmonella spp. is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD. Additionally, Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium.
❌ Haemophilus influenzae:
Incorrect: This patient’s history and presentation are characteristic of sickle cell disease (SCD) with osteomyelitis. SCD places her at increased risk for infection with encapsulated organisms due to functional asplenia. However, the widespread use of the H. influenzae type b vaccine and the presence of gram-negative rods on the blood culture make Salmonella spp. more likely.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe pain in her lower back and hips that started 48 hours ago. Over the past several months, she has had similar, but less severe, episodes of pain in her arms and legs which she initially attributed to physical exertion. She has also had a 2-week history of profound fatigue, pallor, and dark urine. During childhood, she experienced recurrent respiratory infections. Her family is originally from West Africa, and she was born there. Her younger brother has had similar episodes of bone pain. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate is 115/min, blood pressure is 118/68 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals scleral icterus and jaundice. The low back and hip joints are painful with movement and palpation. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on further evaluation?

choices.text: Presence of hemoglobin S on hemoglobin electrophoresis
Decreased hemoglobin A and increased hemoglobin A2 and F on hemoglobin electrophoresis
Presence of bite cells on peripheral blood smear

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of recurrent acute painful episodes of bone pain and fatigue, pallor, jaundice, scleral icterus, and family history of similar painful episodes in a first-degree relative strongly suggests sickle cell disease (SCD). Hemoglobin electrophoresis can be used to diagnose SCD and will show the presence of HbS and reduced or absent hemoglobin A levels.   

SCD is an autosomal recessive hemoglobinopathy caused by a point mutation in the beta-globin gene, which leads to the synthesis of abnormal hemoglobin S (HbS) instead of normal hemoglobin A, which results in sickling of red blood cells. The severe pain in this patient’s lower back and hips indicates a vaso-occlusive crisis, which is a hallmark of SCD, caused by obstruction of small blood vessels by sickled RBCs leading to tissue ischemia and infarction. Vaso-occlusive episodes can affect any organ.  



Option Analysis

✅ Presence of hemoglobin S on hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased hemoglobin A and increased hemoglobin A2 and F on hemoglobin electrophoresis:
Incorrect: This pattern is suggestive of beta thalassemia, a condition that results in reduced synthesis of the beta chains of hemoglobin. While beta thalassemia can present with anemia and jaundice, recurrent acute painful episodes are more consistent with vaso-occlusion from sickle cell disease (SCD).
❌ Presence of bite cells on peripheral blood smear:
Incorrect: Bite cells can be seen in conditions with oxidative hemolysis, such as glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. While G6PD deficiency can lead to lower back pain, hemolysis, and dark urine following oxidative stress, the chronicity of this patient’s symptoms, history of recurrent infections, and family history of similar symptoms makes sickle cell disease more likely.
❌ Positive osmotic fragility test:
Incorrect: This result is diagnostic for hereditary spherocytosis, a condition characterized by the production of spherical red blood cells prone to hemolysis. While these patients may present with jaundice and hemolysis, they typically have splenomegaly and do not experience recurrent acute painful episodes.
❌ Positive direct Coombs test:
Incorrect: A positive direct Coombs test indicates autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) in which destruction of RBCs can lead to jaundice and anemia. The chronicity of this patient’s symptoms, history of recurrent infections, and family history of similar symptoms makes sickle cell disease more likely.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the gastroenterologist for upper abdominal discomfort, acid reflux, and nausea for the past six months. The symptoms are worse at night when she is lying in bed. She has a past medical history of hypertension and diabetes for which she takes amlodipine and metformin. The patient drinks two alcoholic beverages daily. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 136/70 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Oropharyngeal examination reveals halitosis and dental enamel erosions. Abdominal examination is benign. The patient undergoes endoscopy, which reveals superficial erosions and histopathology demonstrating friable mucosa. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs, symptoms, and exam findings consistent with reflux esophagitis. The most appropriate initial treatment for this condition is acid suppression with a proton pump inhibitor (e.g. omeprazole) and lifestyle modifications, such as losing weight if indicated, raising the head of the bed, and decreasing alcohol and caffeine intake. Patients with reflux esophagitis should also have regular screening endoscopies for adenocarcinoma.  

The management of esophagitis should be directed by the specific subtype diagnosed. Patients with pill esophagitis should have the causative agent discontinued. Patients with viral or candidal esophagitis should receive the appropriate antifungal or antiviral agent. Eosinophilic esophagitis is treated with corticosteroids and lifestyle modifications, like limiting exposure to known allergens. Radiation esophagitis is largely managed symptomatically with treatments such as topical anesthetics, systemic analgesics, acid suppression, and lifestyle modifications. Refractory esophagitis may require surgical treatment with dilatation, ablation, or fundoplication—depending on the cause and the severity.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer omeprazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administer acyclovir:
Incorrect: Viral esophagitis typically occurs in patients with underlying immunosuppression (e.g. HIV). This patient has signs, symptoms, and histopathologic features of reflux esophagitis. 
❌ Administer fluconazole:
Incorrect: Esophageal candidiasis typically occurs in patients with underlying immunosuppression (e.g. HIV). Patients will typically have evidence of oral thrush. 
❌ Discontinue amlodipine:
Incorrect: Pill esophagitis typically presents in patients who take agents known to cause pill esophagitis, especially if taken with little or no water before bed. These include bisphosphonates, tetracycline antibiotics, and NSAIDs. Amlodipine does not typically cause pill esophagitis.
❌ Administer prednisone:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for eosinophilic esophagitis. This specific subtype of esophagitis is found in patients with atopic conditions (e.g. asthma) and occurs due to chronic inflammation of the esophagus caused by antigen sensitization.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a six-month history of weight gain and fatigue. She says she always feels cold and has to continuously cover-up. She initially attributed these symptoms to a recent divorce. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 53/min, and blood pressure is 110/95 mmHg. Palpation of the neck reveals a smooth, non-tender anterior mass. The patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Laboratory studies show TSH of 12.3 mIU/L, a free T4 of 0.71 mIU/L, and the presence of anti-Tg antibodies. Which of the following additional findings is most consistent with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with fatigue, weight gain, dry skin, cold intolerance, elevated TSH and low free T4 has primary hypothyroidism. The presence of antithyroid (anti-TPO) or antithyroglobulin (anti-Tg) antibodies confirms the diagnosis of Hashimoto Thyroiditis. On physical examination patients with hypothyroidism can have bradycardia, delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes, peripheral edema, palpable (non-tender) smooth goiter, and diastolic hypertension.

Central hypothyroidism is another cause of hypothyroidism. It is a non-autoimmune cause of hypothyroidism and results in insufficient stimulation of the thyroid gland by TSH. It is either caused by hypothalamic (tertiary) or pituitary (secondary) disease. This should be suspected in cases where there is known hypothalamic or pituitary disease, a pituitary mass, or when hypothyroidism symptoms are associated with abnormal hormonal levels typically with both a low TSH and free T4.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diastolic hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism typically presents with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, and heat intolerance. Hypothyroidism is typically associated with constipation.  
❌ Hypothermia:
Incorrect: Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening form of hypothyroidism that presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, hypoventilation, and lethargy. This patient is stable and therefore would not likely have hypothermia.  
❌ TSH receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Antibodies to TSH receptors are suggestive of Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Patients with Graves disease typically present with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, eye pain, and heat intolerance.  
❌ Diaphoresis:
Incorrect: Tachycardia, heat intolerance, diaphoresis, increased appetite, and weight loss can be seen in Hashitoxicosis which rarely may be an early stage of Hashimoto thyroiditis. This patient is in the hypothyroidism phase.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with fatigue and constipation. She works as a corporate lawyer and has been working 80-hour weeks for the past three months. She also reports weight gain of 6.8 kg (15 lb) and episodes of sadness during the past six months. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 115/95 mmHg. The patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Laboratory studies show a TSH level of 12.3 mIU/L, free T4 of 0.70 mIU/L, and the presence of anti-TPO antibodies. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Fatigue, constipation, weight gain, depression, and results of laboratory studies are suggestive of primary hypothyroidism in this patient. Primary hypothyroidism is most commonly caused by Hashimoto thyroiditis in iodine-sufficient parts of the world. In some cases, patients have a period of hyperthyroidism followed by chronic hypothyroidism. In a stable patient presenting with Hashimoto thyroiditis who has a TSH level greater than 10 mIU/L, treatment consists of thyroid replacement therapy with levothyroxine.

Once treatment with levothyroxine has been started, patients should be reevaluated 3-6 weeks later to assess treatment response. If TSH levels are normal, current dosing should be continued. If TSH levels are still elevated, the dose should be uptitrated until TSH levels have normalized. Patients typically require lifelong therapy and should be routinely followed up at least once a year. The primary goal of treatment is to achieve a euthyroid state.  

Option Analysis

✅ Levothyroxine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stress dose glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Myxedema coma presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, hypoventilation, and lethargy and is a severe, life-threatening form of hypothyroidism. Treatment consists of supportive care (eg, ventilatory support), corticosteroids, and thyroid replacement therapy). Given the lack of these findings and evidence of a moderately elevated (and not severely elevated) TSH, this patient does not have myxedema coma.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Hashitoxicosis can be treated with beta-blockers. It is a rare phase of hyperthyroidism that can be seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis. This patient has clinical findings and lab studies consistent with hypothyroidism.  
❌ Radioiodine therapy:
Incorrect: Graves disease can be treated with radioiodine therapy. It is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism and presents with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, diarrhea, and heat intolerance.  
❌ Vitamin B12:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency can present with fatigue (macrocytic anemia) and glossitis (macroglossia). However, given the constellation of findings in this patient, vitamin B12 deficiency is not a likely diagnosis, and vitamin B12 supplementation would not be an appropriate treatment.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her roommate after ingesting an unknown quantity of acetaminophen tablets. The patient states that she ingested the tablets about 1 hour ago, but she is uncertain about the quantity. She states that she was feeling “overwhelmed and hopeless” about upcoming exams. She currently has no symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable, and she takes no regular medications. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, she appears anxious but is otherwise alert and oriented. Her pupils are equal and reactive, and her skin is cool to the touch. Abdominal examination reveals no tenderness or hepatomegaly. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital for observation only

questions.solution:
This asymptomatic patient presents after ingesting an uncertain amount of acetaminophen within 1 hour of her presentation to the emergency department, placing her at risk for acetaminophen toxicity. Although she is currently asymptomatic, prompt intervention is essential to prevent absorption of the ingested drug and mitigate potential liver damage. Administering activated charcoal is the immediate step to limit further absorption. Activated charcoal binds to drugs in the gastrointestinal tract, reducing systemic absorption. It is most effective when given within 1-2 hours of ingestion of the toxic substance, but can be given up to 4 hours post-ingestion of acetaminophen.

Acetaminophen toxicity presents in four distinct stages. Initially, within 30 minutes to 24 hours post-ingestion, patients may be asymptomatic or exhibit nonspecific symptoms like anorexia, nausea, vomiting, malaise, pallor, and excessive sweating. As toxicity progresses to the hepatic stage (18-72 hours post-ingestion), early symptoms may slightly abate, but liver damage becomes evident. Patients often report right upper quadrant abdominal pain due to liver swelling, and hepatomegaly can be detected on examination. Blood tests may reveal elevated liver enzymes. The next stage is hepatic failure (72-96 hours post-ingestion). At this point, the liver's compromised function manifests as jaundice, confusion or altered mental status, and hepatic encephalopathy due to synthetic liver dysfunction as evidenced by elevated PT and INR, and hypoglycemia. Finally, stage IV, (4 days to 3 weeks), is a period of recovery, during which the patient’s liver function may gradually improve, leading to improved symptoms.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer activated charcoal:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiate hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is not effective for acetaminophen poisoning, as acetaminophen is metabolized by the liver and not excreted by the kidneys.  
❌ Perform gastric lavage:
Incorrect: Gastric lavage is not the primary therapy in the acute treatment of acetaminophen toxicity. Several studies have found that patients treated with activated charcoal had a greater decrease in serum acetaminophen concentrations than those treated with gastric lavage or an emesis-inducing drug.  
❌ Admit to the hospital for observation only:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal should be given for suspected acetaminophen overdose within 4 hours of ingestion to decrease absorption regardless of whether or not symptoms are present.  
❌ Administer sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is the standard initial therapy for hypotension or arrhythmia due to tricyclic antidepressant toxicity. However, it is not used in the acute management of acetaminophen toxicity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with nausea, vomiting, and malaise over the past 12 hours. She states that she took an unknown quantity of acetaminophen tablets about 22 hours ago after an argument with her partner. Her past medical history is significant for depression, for which she takes sertraline. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals pallor but is otherwise unremarkable. Her abdomen is soft and nontender without hepatomegaly. Initial laboratory findings are within normal limits, including liver enzymes. Which of the following is the best next step in evaluation?

choices.text: Admit to the psychiatric unit for evaluation
Observe and repeat liver function tests in 2 hours

questions.solution:
This patient presents with nonspecific symptoms including nausea, vomiting, and malaise following known acetaminophen ingestion. When patients present with potential acetaminophen overdose, serum acetaminophen level is used to guide management with N-acetylcysteine (NAC).

Overdosing on acetaminophen can lead to profound hepatotoxicity and life-threatening acute liver failure. Plotting the serum acetaminophen level on a Rumack-Matthew Nomogram is used to evaluate the risk of hepatotoxicity after an acute acetaminophen overdose. A serum acetaminophen concentration should be taken 4-24 hours after ingestion. This concentration is plotted on the nomogram to determine the likelihood of hepatotoxicity. If the acetaminophen concentration surpasses the treatment threshold on the nomogram, it signifies an elevated risk of liver injury, and N-acetylcysteine (NAC) should be given.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain serum acetaminophen level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Order liver ultrasound:
Incorrect: While liver ultrasound can detect structural abnormalities, it cannot detect early acetaminophen-induced hepatotoxicity and is not used to guide acute management.  
❌ Admit to the psychiatric unit for evaluation:
Incorrect: While psychiatric evaluation is crucial after stabilization, determining the risk of acetaminophen toxicity is the immediate priority.  
❌ Administer N-acetylcysteine (NAC)  :
Incorrect: While NAC is the antidote for acetaminophen overdose, administration should be guided by findings from the Rumack-Matthew Nomogram, which first requires a serum acetaminophen level.    
❌ Observe and repeat liver function tests in 2 hours:
Incorrect: Liver enzymes may remain normal in the initial hours post-ingestion. Relying on them alone can delay necessary treatment. The nomogram provides a more accurate risk assessment to guide administration of NAC.

questions.text: A 46-year-old man presents to the hospital with four days of cough, fever, and shortness of breath. Chest X-ray shows left lower lobe pneumonia. The patient is administered 500 mg of an oral antibiotic, which has a pKA of -5. The antibiotic is transported across intestinal cell membranes via an ATP-mediated transporter. 98% of the original antibiotic dose is present in the bloodstream. Plasma concentration of the antibiotic is measured later and found to be 250 mg/L. The majority of the antibiotic freely diffuses from the bloodstream into tissues. Which of the following attributes correctly describes the antibiotic given to this patient?
questions.solution:
Pharmacodynamics (the action of a medication on the body) and pharmacokinetics (the action of the body on a medication) are critical concepts in pharmacology. Bioavailability refers to the proportion of a medication that reaches circulation. Since intravenous (IV) medications are delivered directly into the bloodstream, their bioavailability is said to be 1, or 100%. Ingested medications have varying amounts of bioavailability, thus making IV medications more effective in many cases. However, some oral medications have such high bioavailability that they are almost equivalent to IV doses. As a medication passes through the GI tract, some of it may be delivered to the liver and partially metabolized, leaving less medication available for later delivery to the target tissue. This is referred to as the first-pass effect. In addition, the medication also needs to diffuse across cellular membranes to eventually be delivered to the target tissue, further potentially lowering the bioavailability.  

The pKA of a medication is used to measure the relative acid strength; medications with a weaker pKA (more positive) are weaker acids and tend to be absorbed better in acidic environments (e.g. the proximal duodenum). Weak base medicines are absorbed better in basic environments (e.g. the distal ileum).   The volume of distribution of a medication refers to how much a medication distributes through the body compartments. A medication with a low volume of distribution (e.g. 5 liters) is mostly found in the plasma. A medication with a high volume of distribution (e.g. 60 liters) will be found throughout all body compartments.  

Option Analysis

❌ Weak acid:
Incorrect: pKA is a measure of an acid’s strength – the higher (more positive) the pKA the number, the weaker an acid is. Acids with a negative pKA are strong acids.
❌ Does not require active transport:
Incorrect: The antibiotic was transported across intestinal cell membranes via ATP-dependent transporters.
❌ Highly albumin-bound:
Incorrect: Highly albumin-bound medications have much lower free medication concentrations in the bloodstream and do not quickly diffuse into tissues. This medication quickly and freely diffuses into tissues.
❌ High volume of distribution:
Incorrect: This medication’s volume of distribution is 2 liters and is calculated by dividing the medication dose by the plasma concentration (500 mg / 250 mg/L in this case). 2 liters is a very small volume of distribution, meaning the drug is mostly found in plasma.
✅ High bioavailability:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to his physician’s office to evaluate a lower extremity rash. The patient visited several months ago to evaluate mild trembling of his hands and a slow, shuffling gait. The physician started the patient on an anti-Parkinsonian medication at the time. The patient states that his tremors have improved, but he noticed a rash on his lower legs several weeks after starting the medication. The rash is not itchy or painful. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals a widespread, patchy rash on the lower legs as shown in the image below. Which of the following medications is the most likely the cause of this patient’s current skin condition?


Reproduced from: Store Norske Leksikon
questions.solution:
This patient, who has signs and symptoms of Parkinson disease, was recently initiated on an anti-Parkinson medication and is now presenting with bilateral lower extremity rashes. The reticular, lacy nature suggests livedo reticularis, likely caused by recent amantadine use.    

Amantadine is an antiviral medication that was found to have antiparkinsonian activity. Studies have demonstrated that amantadine acts on dopaminergic neurons as a weak, non-competitive antagonist of the NMDA receptor, where it increases dopamine release and prevents dopamine reuptake. The primary clinical use of amantadine includes treatment of early PD, although it can be used as adjunctive treatment with levodopa.  

Central side effects associated with amantadine include confusion, hallucinations, insomnia, and nightmares. These are more common in older patients but can occur in patients of any age. Peripheral side effects include livedo reticularis and ankle edema; however, these side effects are typically benign and not treatment-limiting. The mechanism of amantadine-induced livedo reticularis is thought to occur secondary to altered catecholamine metabolism, which induces vasoconstriction in the dermal arterioles and limits flow to the capillary skin surface.  

Option Analysis

✅ Amantadine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Selegiline:
Incorrect: Selegiline, an MAO-B inhibitor, is often used in patients <65 years of age with mild Parkinson symptoms. A major side effect of MAO-B inhibitors includes drug interactions. Although interactions with SSRIs or SNRIs are rare, these two classes of medications should be used with caution due to the risk of precipitating serotonin syndrome. Other side effects of MAO-B inhibitors include CNS depression, dyskinesias, and hypertension.  
❌ Levodopa:
Incorrect: Levodopa is a common medication used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. Typical side effects include nausea and vomiting. This patient presents with evidence of livedo reticularis, which is likely caused by a different medication. 
❌ Trihexyphenidyl:
Incorrect: Trihexyphenidyl, an anticholinergic, can be used as an adjunctive treatment for tremors. Anticholinergics have an extensive adverse effect profile, especially among elderly patients. These side effects include memory impairment, confusion, and hallucinations. 
❌ Pramipexole:
Incorrect: Pramipexole, a dopamine agonist, can be used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. Adverse effects include somnolence and impulse control disorders (e.g., gambling, hypersexuality).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic for regular follow-up. He currently has no symptoms other than fatigue, which he attributes to an increased workload. Past medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no regular medications except occasional ibuprofen for joint pain in the hands. He does not smoke cigarettes and does not drink alcohol. Family history is significant for liver transplantation in the patient's brother at age 40 due to end-stage liver disease. Temperature is 37oC (98.6 F), heart rate is 80 bpm, respirations are 18, and blood pressure is 130/95 mmHg. The patient’s skin appears bronze. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. On abdominal examination, the lower border of the right liver lobe is felt 5 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following represents the primary management for this patient’s diagnosis?

 Laboratory value   Results 
 Hemoglobin   14 g/dl 
 Platelets   165000 / mm3 
 Leukocyte count   7500/mm3 
 INR   1.1 
 Iron   430 µg/l 
 Ferritin  560 μg/L 
 Transferrin saturation  69% 
 AST  96 U/L 
 ALT   60 U/L 
 Albumin   3.6 g/dl 
 Bilirubin (Total)  0.6 mg/dl 
 HBA1C  8%
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of fatigue, arthropathy, family history of liver transplantation, and elevated serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation levels strongly point to a diagnosis of primary hemochromatosis. Regular phlebotomy is the mainstay of treatment for patients with primary hemochromatosis without heart failure or end-stage liver disease. The frequency of the phlebotomy is tailored to the iron profile. The target ferritin level is < 300 μg/L. Importantly, hemoglobin levels should be checked before each phlebotomy session with a target hemoglobin level of 12-13 g/dl. For patients with primary hemochromatosis who have a  contraindication to phlebotomy (e.g., anemia, heart failure, poor venous access) or in cases where phlebotomy has been inadequate, chelating agents like deferasirox can be used.  

An alternative treatment option to phlebotomy is erythrocytapheresis, which involves the selective removal of red blood cells without removing blood components, such as proteins and thrombocytes. Erythrocytapheresis should be considered in patients with thrombocytopenia or hypoproteinemia. In patients with end-stage liver failure, surgery should be consulted to evaluate for liver transplantation. In addition to phlebotomy, patients should be counseled on lifestyle modifications including avoidance of alcohol which can increase the risk of cirrhosis in an already susceptible liver, and avoidance of iron and vitamin C supplements. Genetic screening and counseling should be offered to all first-degree relatives of patients with primary hemochromatosis.  

Patients with hemochromatosis have an increased risk of cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma and should have a thorough liver assessment. If liver fibrosis is indicated by persistently elevated liver function tests, or if the serum ferritin levels are greater than 1000 nanograms per milliliter, abdominal ultrasound with elastography, an MRI of the liver, or liver biopsy should be performed to determine the presence and degree of fibrosis, and to predict progression to cirrhosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Phlebotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Dexrazoxane:
Incorrect: Dexrazoxane is an iron-chelating agent used to lessen the iron-mediated oxidative effect of doxorubicin (i.e., a chemotherapeutic agent) on cardiac muscle.
❌ Desferasirox:
Incorrect: Deferasirox is an iron chelating agent used in patients with primary hemochromatosis when regular phlebotomy is contraindicated or inadequate (e.g., anemia, heart failure, poor venous access).
❌ Liver transplantation:
Incorrect:  Liver transplantation is indicated in patients with end-stage liver disease. This patient has normal albumin, INR, and total bilirubin with mild elevations in the liver enzymes (e.g., AST, ALT) and does not need liver transplantation at this time.
❌ Vitamin C supplementation:
Incorrect: Vitamin C supplementation increases the ferrous form of iron, thus increasing iron absorption. Like alcohol, vitamin C should be avoided in patients with hemochromatosis.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 6-month history of joint pain. The pain is localized to his fingers and toes, and he has no history of trauma to the areas. The pain is worse in the morning and is associated with swelling. He says he is able to perform his job on the computer, but he is limited to approximately an hour each morning. He has a 7-year history of psoriasis. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 117/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows swelling of 5 distal and proximal joints of the fingers and 3 distal and proximal joints of the toes with tenderness to palpation without deformities. Nail findings are seen, as shown in the image below. Skin exam is significant for multiple erythematous and scaly plaques on both elbows and the buttocks. Laboratory studies reveal C-reactive protein (CRP) of 6 mg/L and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) (22 mm/hr). Radiographic findings show joint space narrowing in 3 distal interphalangeal joints of the fingers without evidence of pencil-in-cup deformities. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?


Image taken from Wikimedia
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of skin psoriasis presents with pain, swelling, and tenderness of multiple distal joints of the hands and feet, nail changes (onycholysis) psoriatic arthritis (PsA), and elevated inflammatory markers. Given this patient’s history, clinical, and radiographic findings, he likely has moderate PsA, and he should be started on treatment with a first-line oral disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) such as methotrexate (along with folic acid supplementation).  

Treatment for PsA is targeted towards disease severity (mild, moderate, or severe). This patient with active psoriasis, multiple joint involvements (>5), nail changes, mild limitations in functioning, and radiographic changes has moderate PsA, and he should be started on treatment with a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD).    

The first line DMARD typically used in PsA is methotrexate (MTX). MTX works by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme essential for folate metabolism. Thus, patients being treated with MTX should also have supplementation with folic acid to prevent folate deficiency. In addition, all patients should be prescribed a topical agent for psoriatic skin lesions.  

After initiating treatment with MTX, patients should be reassessed in three months’ time to determine response to treatment. If joint inflammation persists after three months, then another DMARD such as leflunomide should be considered. If symptoms persist or worsen, then use of a biologics agent (ie tumor necrosis factor, interleukin inhibitor) should be considered.  



Option Analysis

✅ Methotrexate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Topical vitamin D analog:
Incorrect: Topical agents, such as a vitamin D analog, are used to manage psoriatic skin plaques, however, they have no effect on joint disease.
❌ Topical calcineurin inhibitor:
Incorrect: Topical agents, such as a calcineurin inhibitor, are used to manage psoriatic skin plaques, however, they have no effect on joint disease
❌ Secukinumab:
Incorrect: Secukinumab is an interleukin 17 inhibitor that can be used to treat severe PsA that has not been responsive to tumor necrosis factor inhibitors.
❌ Etanercept:
Incorrect: In patients with severe psoriatic arthritis, tumor necrosis factor inhibitors (TNF-inhibitors) such as etanercept or infliximab should be used. However, based on this patient’s presentation and findings, he likely has moderate disease activity, and should first be started on an oral disease-modifying drug like methotrexate.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by police officers after he and several friends were found in an abandoned house producing and using recreational drugs. The patient endorses blurry vision and a headache for the past two hours. Past medical history includes coronary artery disease, hypertension, and treatment-resistant depression. Current medications include aspirin, lisinopril, metoclopramide, metoprolol, and selegiline. Temperature is 99.1 ºF (37.3 ºC), heart rate is 108 bpm, respiratory rate is 18 bpm, blood pressure is 205/116 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and slightly confused. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia and an S4 sound. The neurologic exam is unremarkable. Several of the patient’s friends demonstrated evidence of slow movement, rigidity, and a resting tremor on physical examination. Which of this patient’s medications protected him from experiencing the physical exam findings observed in his friends?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a hypertensive crisis, presumably a hypertensive emergency in light of his altered mental status. Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOI), such as selegiline, can cause serotonin syndrome when combined with other serotonergic medications and can also lead to hypertensive crises. Selegiline is an MAO-B subtype-specific MAOI that is often used to treat Parkinson disease given its role in dopamine metabolism.  

This patient’s friends have likely been exposed to the neurotoxin MPTP, which can be produced as an unintended product during the synthesis of recreational drugs (e.g. opioids). MPTP and its active metabolites can induce damage to the substantia nigra and result in the development of Parkinsonian features. Since MPTP cannot be broken down into active metabolites by MAO-B, selegiline offers a relative neuroprotective effect against MPTP neurotoxicity.

Option Analysis

❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: While aspirin can help prevent cerebrovascular accidents, which can cause permanent neurologic changes, it is unlikely that it is preventing Parkinsonism.
❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril can help reduce risk of myocardial infarction, ventricular remodeling and inappropriate renin-angiotensin-aldosterone activity, it does not prevent the development of Parkinsonism.
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is an anti-dopaminergic agent that can cause Parkinsonism features.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol does not prevent Parkinsonism
✅ Selegiline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is referred to the nephrology clinic after serum creatinine was found to be elevated. The patient underwent a renal transplantation one month ago and is currently not experiencing any symptoms. The patient developed end-stage renal disease 5 years ago after a severe acute kidney injury from septic shock. The patient underwent three times weekly hemodialysis until receiving a kidney donation from a family member. Current medications include cyclosporine and sirolimus. The patient does not use tobacco or drink alcohol. Temperature is 37.1C (98.78F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 145/89 mmHg. Select laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of elevated serum creatinine in this patient?

 Complete Blood Count (CBC)
 Hemoglobin  12.7 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  45% 
 Leukocyte count  2500/mm3 
 Platelet count  200,000/mm3 
 Complete Metabolic Panel (CMP)
 Sodium  138 mEg/L 
 Potassium  4.3 mEq/L 
 Calcium  8.3 mg/dL 
 Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)  55 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  2.2 mg/dL 
 Urinalysis
 Protein  Negative 
 Glucose  Negative 
 Blood  Negative 
 Casts  Few hyaline 
 Leukocyte esterase  Negative 
 Nitrites  Negative
questions.solution:
This patient has developed an elevation in serum creatinine after kidney transplantation. Absence of significant findings on urinalysis and the elevated BUN/creatinine ratio suggests a prerenal cause. This is most likely due to afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction caused by cyclosporine.  

Cyclosporine is a calcineurin inhibitor that is used frequently to prevent transplant rejection and can also be used in treatment of certain autoimmune disorders. Normally, after T-cells are exposed to an antigen, calcineurin gets activated and dephosphorylates a transcription factor known as the Nuclear Factor of Activated T cells (NFAT). NFAT then translocates to the nucleus and induces transcription of immune mediator cytokines; most importantly interleukin-2 (IL-2). IL-2 provides the signal needed for T-cell activation and proliferation. Cyclosporine inhibits the transcription of IL-2 by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby halting T cell proliferation and protecting the transplanted organ from T cell-mediated injury.    

One of the major limitations of cyclosporine use is its severe nephrotoxic effects. Acute nephrotoxicity is related to afferent arteriolar vasoconstriction, which decreases the glomerular filtration rate, renal plasma flow, and creatinine clearance. As there is no intrinsic kidney injury, the urinalysis is usually bland. This is usually reversible with cyclosporine dose reduction. Long-term use can cause chronic nephrotoxicity marked by tubulointerstitial fibrosis, which is usually irreversible. Cyclosporine can also cause hypertension, gingival hyperplasia, hirsutism, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.  



Option Analysis

✅ Cyclosporine side effect:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Sirolimus side effect:
Incorrect: Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant that is frequently used in combination with cyclosporine as a prophylaxis for transplant rejection. However, unlike calcineurin inhibitors, sirolimus is not known to have any nephrotoxic effects.
❌ Acute kidney transplant rejection:
Incorrect:  Acute graft rejection usually occurs in the first 6 months post-transplant. It can be asymptomatic or the patient may have fever, malaise, oliguria and graft tenderness. Urinalysis however usually shows pyuria and proteinuria.
❌ Chronic transplant rejection:
Incorrect: Chronic kidney transplant rejection happens after the first year of transplant and manifests with gradually declining kidney function, worsening hypertension, and increasing proteinuria on urinalysis.
❌ BK virus reactivation:
Incorrect: BK polyoma virus is a DNA virus that infects renal tubules in many people and remains quiescent. It can get reactivated in transplanted kidneys and may lead to graft failure. Reactivation is usually asymptomatic and is detected as an increase in serum creatinine. However, urinalysis usually shows pyuria, hematuria, and tubular casts.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the nephrology clinic for a follow-up appointment. The patient previously had end-stage renal disease secondary to adult polycystic kidney disease and underwent kidney transplantation 5 years ago. The patient is currently on maintenance treatment with an immunosuppressant that inhibits the activation of T cells by inhibiting intracellular response to cytokines. Which of the following is a known side effect of this immunosuppressant?
questions.solution:
This patient previously underwent kidney transplantation and in order to prevent organ rejection was given sirolimus. Sirolimus is an immunosuppressant frequently used in renal transplant patients that works by inhibiting the proliferation of lymphocytes in response to cytokines.    

When sirolimus enters T cells, it binds to a protein called FK-binding protein (FKBP) and inhibits mTOR (mammalian target of rapamycin). In IL-2-activated cells, mTOR becomes activated and promotes cellular growth and proliferation. Therefore, inhibiting mTOR sirolimus blocks the proliferation of immune cells in response to cytokines.  

Sirolimus is specifically indicated in renal transplantation to prevent rejection. It is frequently used in combination with cyclosporine due to synergistic immunosuppressive effects. Additionally, sirolimus is used in cardiac stents as a drug-eluting agent to prevent intimal proliferation and restenosis from induced inflammatory response.

Unlike calcineurin inhibitors, sirolimus is not nephrotoxic. However, sirolimus can lead to severe bone marrow suppression and pancytopenia. Hyperglycemia and hyperlipidemia are other known side effects of sirolimus.



Option Analysis

❌ Nephrotoxicity:
Incorrect: Sirolimus inhibits the immune cells’ response to cytokines. One of the major advantages of sirolimus is the lack of nephrotoxic effects, which are commonly associated with calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus, and cyclosporine). Calcineurin inhibitors impair the synthesis of (not response to) cytokines.
✅ Pancytopenia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Neurotoxicity:
Incorrect: Neurotoxicity is mainly associated with the use of tacrolimus, although it can be less commonly seen in cyclosporine. Both tacrolimus and cyclosporine are calcineurin inhibitors that decrease the synthesis of cytokines. Sirolimus is not associated with neurotoxicity.
❌ Gingival hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is a known side effect of cyclosporine. It is not seen in patients taking sirolimus. 
❌ Macrocytosis:
Incorrect: Macrocytosis is seen with certain drugs like hydroxyurea and methotrexate. However, sirolimus is not known to cause macrocytosis.

questions.text: A medication is currently under study for treating cerebral salt wasting syndrome. It is currently in use in rat models and has demonstrated potent effects on the distal tubules of the kidneys. This medication has been found to act on both α-intercalated cells and principal cells by increasing the activity of the hydrogen ion ATPase and apical potassium conductance, respectively. Which of the following physiologic side effects is most likely to be observed due to the mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
The medication works on both intercalated cells and principal cells in the distal tubules by increasing the activity of the hydrogen ion ATPase and increasing apical potassium conductance. This mechanism of action is consistent with that of aldosterone. Aldosterone, a mineralocorticoid, will ultimately result in hypertension and hypernatremia due to the retention of sodium and osmotic shifts.    

Aldosterone binds to aldosterone receptors on α-intercalated cells and principal cells in the collecting tubule of the nephron. In α-intercalated cells, aldosterone induces increased secretion of hydrogen ions into the collecting duct lumen by promoting both the synthesis and activity of the H+/K+ exchange transporter. In principal cells, aldosterone works to increase the synthesis and activity of the Na+/K+ ion transporter. These changes result in increased potassium secretion into the collecting duct and retention of sodium in the blood.    

The net effect of aldosterone is thus increased sodium retention, thereby increasing hydrostatic pressure and, as a surrogate, blood pressure. Secretion of hydrogen ions into the collecting duct increases physiologic pH, resulting in metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia due to the loss of potassium ions.   

Option Analysis

✅ Hypertension and hypernatremia :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hypotension and hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: Hypotension and hyperkalemia are the effects seen in the absence of aldosterone, or primary hypoaldosteronism. 
❌ Hypertension and hyperkalemia :
Incorrect: Hypokalemia is likely to be observed with mineralocorticoids, not hyperkalemia. 
❌ Hypotension and hypocalcemia:
Incorrect: Mineralocorticoids do not affect calcium homeostasis and thus are unlikely to cause hypocalcemia. 
❌ Hypertension and hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Aldosterone can induce hypertension, but mineralocorticoids do not affect calcium homeostasis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the clinic because of bilateral leg “heaviness and aching pain” with prolonged standing. The patient reports that the pain worsens at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and obesity. Family history is noncontributory. The patient smokes two packs daily and does not use alcohol or other recreational drugs. BMI is 35 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination of the lower extremities demonstrates dilated, tortuous veins at the calves and ankles bilaterally, without surrounding erythema, edema, or ulceration. A bluish non-tender lump is noted in the right upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, that disappears with continuous, direct pressure and with lying supine. No pulsations are felt and no inguinal defect is palpated. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s groin swelling?
questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is consistent with lower limb varicosities, most likely due to prolonged standing and obesity, as well as a bluish-tinged, nontender, reducible groin lump suggestive of a saphena varix.   

Saphena varix is a dilated, saccular swelling of the great saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction in the groin below the inguinal ligament. They arise from incompetent valves, which permit blood flow from the deep venous system to the superficial venous system. Thus the leg of the affected side almost always has obvious varicose veins as well which are tortuous dilated segments of a vein associated with valvular incompetence. This results in venous hypertension and dilatation of the superficial venous system. Valvular incompetence of the deep and superficial veins can be determined by performing a Trendelenburg test. The affected leg is raised emptying the veins, then a tourniquet is applied to constrict only the superficial veins. The test is positive, if upon standing with the tourniquet in place for 30 seconds, the varicosities remain collapsed and when the tourniquet is removed, the internal saphenous vein rapidly fills with blood from above. This indicates that the valves of the saphenous vein at the saphenofemoral junction are incompetent, but the valves of the communicating veins are still intact.  



Option Analysis

❌ Femoral hernia:
Incorrect: A femoral hernia results when the abdominal viscera passes through the femoral ring. The inguinal defect can typically be palpated. This condition manifests as a tender or non-tender bulge on the upper thigh, inferior to the inguinal ligament, and can often be mistaken for a saphena varix..
❌ Femoral artery aneurysm:
Incorrect: A femoral artery aneurysm refers to dilation of the common femoral artery just below the inguinal ligament. Pain is typically absent in femoral artery aneurysms and the palpable mass is typically pulsatile. 
✅ Saphena varix:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Direct inguinal hernia:
Incorrect: Inguinal hernias are located above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle. This patient’s groin lump is located below the inguinal ligament.
❌ Inguinal lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Enlarged inguinal lymph nodes vary in consistency, number, presence of pain, and size depending on the pathological cause. Lymph nodes are not reducible.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right buttock pain for three months. The patient describes the pain as dull with intermittent radiation to the right thigh and leg. The pain increases with prolonged sitting. He is currently training for a marathon that requires downhill running. The patient does not have back pain, bowel or bladder symptoms, or trauma history. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation of the right buttock. Lower extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally, and sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. Straight leg raise is positive on the right lower extremity. Forceful internal rotation at the hip with the thigh extended reproduces the pain. Plain radiographs and an MRI of the spine and pelvis are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an insidious onset of unilateral buttock pain that radiates to the thigh and leg, aggravated by prolonged sitting. This, in combination with a positive Freibergs test (reproduction of pain with forceful internal rotation of the hip with the thigh extended), is suggestive of Piriformis syndrome.   

Piriformis syndrome refers to a musculoskeletal condition that results from compression of the sciatic nerve as it passes through the piriformis. Compression can result from shortening, hypertrophy, or spasm of the piriformis muscle secondary to trauma or overuse. Symptoms include pain in the buttock area, accompanied by sciatica-like pain, numbness, and weakness that traverses the back of the thigh, calf, and foot. Pain from piriformis syndrome is often worse when walking upstairs, after sitting, or while walking or running. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness in the sciatic notch and often with direct palpation over the piriformis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar spinal stenosis:
Incorrect: Lumbar spinal stenosis presents with neurogenic claudication (i.e. buttock and leg pain, discomfort, sensory loss, and weakness with walking, standing, or maintaining certain postures). This patient’s unilateral buttock pain exacerbated with sitting and tenderness to palpation at the buttocks is consistent with piriformis syndrome.
❌ L1 radiculopathy:
Incorrect: L1 radiculopathy results from intervertebral disc herniation at the L1 level. Symptoms involve pain, paresthesias, sensory loss in the inguinal region, and slight weakness with hip flexion. Unilateral buttock pain with a positive Freibergs test is suggestive of piriformis syndrome.
✅ Piriformis syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Femoroacetabular impingement:
Incorrect: Femoroacetabular impingement syndrome can result from abnormal contact between the anterior femoral head and the acetabular rim. Patients present with insidious onset of groin pain that worsens with activity. Symptoms are most noticeable after sitting with hips flexed to 90 degrees for a  prolonged period (e.g a plane ride). Buttock pain is less common, and plain radiographs can often identify the impingement.
❌ Iliotibial band syndrome:
Incorrect: Iliotibial band (ITB) syndrome refers to an overuse injury of the lateral knee that occurs primarily in runners. Patients describe the insidious onset of pain localized to the lateral femoral epicondyle.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a three-month history of joint pain, fatigue, and a facial rash that appears to worsen with sun exposure. Over the last two weeks, she developed swelling in her ankles and frothy urine. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate is 78/min, blood pressure is 148/93 mmHg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals malar erythema on the cheeks and nose sparing the nasolabial folds, pain and swelling of multiple joints of the hands, and bilateral pitting edema up to the mid-shins. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. Which of the following tests should be performed to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Skin biopsy of the facial rash

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation is highly suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) with classical symptoms, including joint pain, fatigue, and a malar rash exacerbated by sun exposure. Additionally, the presence of hypertension, bilateral lower limb edema, proteinuria, and hematuria are highly suggestive of lupus nephritis; which can be a complication of SLE. A renal biopsy is required to confirm the diagnosis.

The diagnosis of SLE is often based on a combination of clinical criteria and laboratory findings. Key laboratory tests include antinuclear antibody (ANA) titers, which are highly sensitive for SLE but not specific, and anti-double-stranded DNA (anti-dsDNA) and anti-Smith (anti-Sm) antibodies, which are more specific for SLE. Classification criteria for SLE were designed to select patients to enroll in research trials. However, since no single finding or test can diagnose lupus, these criteria can be helpful when evaluating patients with suspected SLE.

When symptoms suggest kidney involvement and findings of proteinuria and hematuria are present, renal biopsy is necessary to diagnose and classify the type of lupus nephritis. The biopsy can confirm lupus nephritis by demonstrating typical immunofluorescence and histopathological features of immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis. Renal biopsy also provides prognostic information and helps classify the type of nephritis, which ranges from minimal involvement (class I) to advanced sclerosing nephritis (class VI). The results are used to guide specific treatment strategies.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Renal biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ ANA titers:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) complicated by lupus nephritis. While ANA titers should be checked as part of the initial evaluation of suspected SLE, they are not specific; and renal biopsy would be needed to confirm lupus nephritis.  
❌ Serum complement levels (C3 and C4)  :
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) complicated by lupus nephritis. Complement levels should be checked as part of the initial evaluation of suspected SLE. Low complement levels can support the diagnosis of SLE, but they are not specific for lupus nephritis; and renal biopsy would be needed to confirm lupus nephritis.  
❌ Skin biopsy of the facial rash:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having systemic lupus erythematosus complicated by lupus nephritis. A skin biopsy can confirm cutaneous lupus, but a kidney biopsy is needed to confirm lupus nephritis.  
❌ 24-hour urinary protein collection:
Incorrect: This patient is suspected of having systemic lupus erythematosus complicated by lupus nephritis. While this test should be part of the evaluation to assess the severity of protein loss in nephrotic and nephritic syndromes, it is not diagnostic for lupus nephritis. A renal biopsy is required for a definitive diagnosis when lupus nephritis is suspected.
